1394922_12_ITEM8_P103_S0	The terms of the Operating Agreement provide that the Managing Member and/or affiliates are entitled to receive certain fees for equipment management and resale and for management of the Company.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P104_S0	The Operating Agreement allows for the reimbursement of costs incurred by Managing Member and/or affiliates for providing administrative services to the Company.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P104_S1	Administrative services provided include Company accounting, investor relations, legal counsel and lease and equipment documentation.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P104_S2	The Managing Member is not reimbursed for services whereby it is entitled to receive a separate fee as compensation for such services, such as management of investments.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P105_S0	The Company will be liable for certain future costs to be incurred by the Managing Member to manage the administrative services provided to the Company.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P106_S0	Each of ATEL Financial Services, LLC ( AFS ) and ATEL Leasing Corporation ( ALC ) is a wholly-owned subsidiary of ATEL Capital Group and performs services for the Company on behalf of the Managing Member.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P106_S1	Acquisition services, equipment management, lease administration and asset disposition services are performed by ALC; investor relations and communications services, and general administrative services are performed by AFS.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P107_S0	Cost reimbursements to the Managing Member or its affiliates are based on its costs incurred in performing administrative services for the Company.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P107_S1	These costs are allocated to each managed entity based on certain criteria such as total assets, number of investors or contributed capital based upon the type of cost incurred.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P107_S2	The Managing Member believes that the costs reimbursed are the lower of (i) actual costs incurred on behalf of the Company or (ii) the amount the Company would be required to pay independent parties for comparable administrative services in the same geographic location.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P108_S0	During the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010, the Managing Member and/or affiliates earned commissions and reimbursements pursuant to the Operating Agreement as follows (in thousands):
1394922_12_ITEM8_P109_S0	During December 2009, operating lease assets were purchased and a lease agreement entered into by the Company with an original cost of $1.7 million.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P109_S1	During the same month, the assets and associated lease were reassigned to an affiliate of the Company resulting in an amount due from an affiliate equivalent to the original cost of the assets.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P109_S2	Such amount due from an affiliate was settled in January 2010.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P110_S0	At December 31, 2011, non-recourse debt consists of notes payable to financial institutions.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P110_S1	The notes are due in monthly installments.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P110_S2	Interest on the notes is at fixed rates ranging from 4.11% to 4.40% per annum.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P110_S3	The notes are secured by assignments of lease payments and pledges of assets.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P110_S4	At December 31, 2011, gross lease rentals totaled approximately $3.0 million over the remaining lease terms; and the carrying value of the pledged assets is approximately $4.0 million.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P110_S5	The notes all mature in 2014.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P111_S0	The non-recourse debt does not contain any material financial covenants.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P111_S1	The debt is secured by liens granted by the Company to the non-recourse lenders on (and only on) the discounted lease transactions.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P111_S2	The lenders have recourse only to the following collateral: the specific leased equipment; the related lease chattel paper; the lease receivables; and proceeds of the foregoing items.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P111_S3	The non-recourse obligation is payable solely out of the respective specific security and the Company does not guarantee (nor is the Company otherwise contractually responsible for) the payment of the non-recourse debt as a general obligation or liability of the Company.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P111_S4	Although the Company does not have any direct or general liability in connection with the non-recourse debt apart from the security granted, the Company is directly and generally liable and responsible for certain representations, warranties, and covenants made to the lenders, such as warranties as to genuineness of the transaction parties signatures, as to the genuineness of the respective lease chattel paper or the transaction as a whole, or as to the Company s good title to or perfected interest in the secured collateral, as well as similar representations, warranties and covenants typically provided by non-recourse borrowers and customary in the equipment finance industry, and are viewed by such industry as being consistent with non-recourse discount financing obligations.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P111_S5	Accordingly, as there are no financial covenants or ratios imposed on the Company in connection with the non-recourse debt, the Company has determined that there are no material covenants with respect to the non-recourse debt that warrant footnote disclosure.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P112_S0	Future minimum payments of non-recourse debt are as follows (in thousands):
1394922_12_ITEM8_P113_S0	The Company participates with AFS and certain of its affiliates in a revolving credit facility (the Credit Facility ) comprised of a working capital facility to AFS, an acquisition facility (the Acquisition Facility ) and a warehouse facility (the Warehouse Facility ) to AFS, the Company and affiliates, and a venture facility available to an affiliate with a syndicate of financial institutions which Credit Facility includes certain financial covenants.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P113_S1	The Credit Facility is for an amount up to $75 million and expires in June 2012.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P113_S2	The lending syndicate providing the Credit Facility has a blanket lien on all of the Company s assets as collateral for any and all borrowings under the Acquisition Facility, and on a pro-rata basis under the Warehouse Facility.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P114_S0	As of December 31, 2011 and 2010, borrowings under the facility were as follows (in thousands):
1394922_12_ITEM8_P115_S0	The Company and its affiliates pay an annual commitment fee to have access to this line of credit.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P115_S1	As of December 31, 2011, the aggregate amount remaining unutilized under the Credit Facility is potentially available to the Company, subject to certain sub-facility and borrowing-base limitations.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P116_S0	each of the Company and the affiliates who are borrowers under the Credit Facility, the amount remaining available to all borrowers to draw under the Credit Facility is reduced.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P116_S1	As the Warehousing Facility is a short term bridge facility, any amounts borrowed under the Warehousing Facility, and then repaid by the affiliated borrowers (including the Company) upon allocation of an acquisition to a specific purchaser, become available under the Warehouse Facility for further short term borrowing.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P117_S0	As of December 31, 2011, the Company s Tangible Net Worth requirement under the Credit Facility was $7.5 million, the permitted maximum leverage ratio was not to exceed 1.25 to 1, and the required minimum interest coverage ratio was not to be less than 2 to 1.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P117_S1	The Company was in compliance with these financial covenants under the Credit Facility with a minimum Tangible Net Worth, leverage ratio and interest coverage ratio, as calculated per the Credit Facility agreement of $14.1 million, 0.20 to 1, and 24.76 to 1, respectively, as of December 31, 2011.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P117_S2	As such, as of December 31, 2011, the Company was in compliance with all material financial covenants, and with all other material conditions of the Credit Facility.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P117_S3	The Company does not anticipate any covenant violations nor does it anticipate that any of these covenants will restrict its operations or its ability to procure additional financing.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P118_S0	The interest rate on the Credit Facility is based on either the LIBOR/Eurocurrency rate of 1-, 2-, 3- or 6-month maturity plus a lender designated spread, or the bank s Prime rate, which re-prices daily.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P119_S0	Principal amounts of loans made under the Credit Facility that are prepaid may be re-borrowed on the terms and subject to the conditions set forth under the Credit Facility.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P119_S1	There were no borrowings outstanding at December 31, 2010.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P119_S2	During the first quarter of 2011, the Company borrowed $632 thousand, of which the whole amount was repaid during the same quarter.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P119_S3	The weighted average interest rate on such borrowings was 3.29% in 2011.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P120_S0	To hold the assets under the Warehousing Facility prior to allocation to specific investor programs, a Warehousing Trust has been entered into by the Company, AFS, ALC, and certain of the affiliated partnerships and limited liability companies.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P120_S1	The Warehousing Trust is used by the Warehouse Facility borrowers to acquire and hold, on a short-term basis, certain lease transactions that meet the investment objectives of each of such entities.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P120_S2	Each of the leasing programs sponsored by AFS and ALC currently in its acquisition stage is a pro rata participant in the Warehousing Trust, as described below.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P120_S3	When a program no longer has a need for short term financing provided by the Warehousing Facility, it is removed from participation, and as new leasing investment entities are formed by AFS and ALC and commence their acquisition stages, these new entities are added.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P121_S0	As of December 31, 2011, the investment program participants were ATEL Capital Equipment Fund X, LLC, ATEL Capital Equipment Fund XI, LLC, the Company and ATEL 14, LLC.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P122_S0	Pursuant to the Warehousing Trust, the benefit of the lease transaction assets, and the corresponding liabilities under the Warehouse Facility, inure to each of such entities based upon each entity s pro-rata share in the Warehousing Trust estate.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P122_S1	The pro-rata share is calculated as a ratio of the net worth of each entity over the aggregate net worth of all entities benefiting from the Warehousing Trust estate, excepting that the trustees, AFS and ALC, are both jointly and severally liable for the pro rata portion of the obligations of each of the affiliated partnerships and limited liability companies participating under the Warehouse Facility.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P122_S2	Transactions are financed through this Warehouse Facility only until the transactions are allocated to a specific program for purchase or are otherwise disposed by AFS and ALC.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P122_S3	When a determination is made to allocate the transaction to a specific program for purchase by the program, the purchaser repays the debt associated with the asset, either with cash or by means of proceeds of a draw under the Acquisition Facility, and the asset is removed from the Warehouse Facility collateral, and ownership of the asset and any debt obligation associated with the asset are assumed solely by the purchasing entity.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P123_S0	Borrowings of $5.6 million and $4.8 million were outstanding under the Warehouse Facility at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P123_S1	The Company s maximum contingent obligation on the outstanding warehouse balances at December 31, 2011 and 2010 were approximately $661 thousand and $1.1 million, respectively.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P124_S0	The terms of the Operating Agreement provided that the Managing Member and/or affiliates are entitled to receive certain fees, in addition to the allocations described above, which are more fully described in Section 8 of the Operating Agreement.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P124_S1	At December 31, 2011, the Company had commitments to purchase lease assets totaling approximately $5.0 million and to fund investments in notes receivable totaling approximately $250 thousand.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P124_S2	These amounts represent contract awards which may be canceled by the prospective lessee or may not be accepted by the Company.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P124_S3	There were no cancellations subsequent to year-end.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P125_S0	The Company enters into contracts that contain a variety of indemnifications.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P125_S1	The Company s maximum exposure under these arrangements is unknown.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P125_S2	However, the Company has not had prior claims or losses pursuant to these contracts and expects the risk of loss to be remote.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P126_S0	The Managing Member knows of no facts or circumstances that would make the Company s contractual commitments outside standard mutual covenants applicable to commercial transactions between businesses.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P126_S1	Accordingly, the Company believes that these indemnification obligations are made in the ordinary course of business as part of standard commercial and industry practice, and that any potential liability under the Company s similar commitments is remote.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P126_S2	Should any such indemnification obligation become payable, the Company would separately record and/or disclose such liability in accordance with GAAP.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P127_S0	A total of 2,993,482 and 2,999,482 Units were issued and outstanding at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P127_S1	The Fund was authorized to issue up to 20,000,000 total Units.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P128_S0	The Company has the right, exercisable in the Manager s discretion, but not the obligation, to repurchase Units of a Unitholder who ceases to be a U.S. Citizen, for a price equal to 100% of the holder s capital account.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P128_S1	The Company is otherwise permitted, but not required, to repurchase Units upon a holder s request.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P128_S2	The repurchase of Fund units is made in accordance with Section 13 of the Amended and Restated Limited Liability Company Operating Agreement.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P128_S3	The repurchase would be at the discretion of the Manager on terms it determines to be appropriate under given circumstances, in the event that the Manager deems such repurchase to be in the best interest of the Company; provided, the Company is never required to repurchase any Units.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P128_S4	Upon the repurchase of any Units by the Fund, the tendered Units are cancelled.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P129_S0	Units repurchased in prior periods were repurchased at amounts representing the original investment less cumulative distributions made to the Unitholder with respect to the Units.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P129_S1	All Units repurchased during a quarter are deemed to be repurchased effective the last day of the preceding quarter, and are not deemed to be outstanding during, or entitled to allocations of net income, net loss or distributions for the quarter in which such repurchase occurs.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P130_S0	The Fund s net income or net losses are to be allocated 100% to the Members.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P130_S1	From the commencement of the Fund until the initial closing date, as defined in the Company s Operating Agreement, net income and net loss shall be allocated 99% to the Managing Member and 1% to the initial Other Members.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P130_S2	Commencing with the initial closing date, net income and net loss shall be allocated 92.5% to the Other Members and 7.5% to the Managing Member.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P130_S3	In accordance with the terms of the Operating Agreement, additional allocations of income were made to the Manager in 2011 and 2010.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P130_S4	The amounts allocated were determined to bring the Manager s ending capital account balance to zero at the end of each year.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P131_S0	Fund distributions are to be allocated 7.5% to the Managing Member and 92.5% to the Other Members.

1394922_12_ITEM8_P132_S0	Fair value measurements and disclosures are based on a fair value hierarchy as determined by significant inputs used to measure fair value.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P132_S1	The three levels of inputs within the fair value hierarchy are defined as follows:
1394922_12_ITEM8_P133_S0	Level 1 Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P134_S0	An active market for the asset or liability is a market in which transactions for the asset or liability occur with sufficient frequency and volume to provide pricing information on an ongoing basis, generally on a national exchange.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P135_S0	Level 2 Quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active, and model-based valuations in which all significant inputs are observable in the market.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P136_S0	Level 3 Valuation is modeled using significant inputs that are unobservable in the market.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P136_S1	These unobservable inputs reflect the Company s own estimates of assumptions that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P137_S0	At December 31, 2011 and 2010, the Company had no assets or liabilities that required measurement at fair value on a recurring basis.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P137_S1	During the first three quarters of 2011, the Company recorded adjustments to reflect the fair value of impaired notes receivable and impaired investment securities on a non-recurring basis.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P137_S2	There were no additional fair value adjustments at December 31, 2011.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P138_S0	At December 31, 2010, the Company recorded adjustments to reflect the value of impaired investments securities on a non-recurring basis.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P138_S1	Such fair value adjustments utilized the following methodology:
1394922_12_ITEM8_P139_S0	The fair value of the Company s notes receivable is estimated using either third party appraisals of collateral or discounted cash flow analyses based upon current market rates for similar types of lending arrangements, with adjustments for non-accrual loans as deemed necessary.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P139_S1	At September 30, 2011, the Company deemed a note receivable impaired based upon an independent appraisal of the underlying collateral.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P139_S2	Accordingly, the Company recorded a non-recurring adjustment totaling $4 thousand which reduced the cost basis of the note.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P140_S0	Under the Fair Value Measurements Topic of the FASB Accounting Standards Codification, the fair value of the impaired notes receivable is classified within Level 3 of the valuation hierarchy.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P141_S0	Such valuation utilizes a market approach technique and uses inputs from third party appraisers that utilize current market transactions as adjusted for certain factors specific to the underlying collateral.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P141_S1	No additional adjustment was deemed necessary at December 31, 2011.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P142_S0	The Company s investment securities are not registered for public sale and are carried at cost.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P142_S1	The investment securities are adjusted for impairment, if any, based upon factors which include, but are not limited to, available financial information, the issuer s ability to meet its current obligations and indications of the issuer s subsequent ability to raise capital.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P142_S2	At June 30, 2011, the Company had recorded a fair value adjustment of $5 thousand which reduced the cost basis of an investment deemed impaired at June 30, 2011.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P142_S3	The non-recurring fair value adjustment was based on an approximate 25% reduction in valuation based on the expected value of shares of the venture company as contemplated in its merger agreement terms.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P142_S4	There was no incremental impairment to investment securities at December 31, 2011.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P143_S0	At December 31, 2010, a fair value adjustment of approximately $356 thousand was recorded relative to an impaired security based on an approximate 79% reduction in valuation as determined by investee cash burn and potential for additional venture investors.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P143_S1	Under the Fair Value Measurements Topic of the FASB Accounting Standards Codification, the fair value of these impaired investment securities are classified within Level 3 of the valuation hierarchy due to the significant inputs that are unobservable in the market.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P144_S0	The following tables present the fair value measurements of impaired assets measured at fair value on a recurring and non-recurring basis during 2011 and 2010, and the level within the hierarchy in which the fair value measurements fall at December 31, 2011 and 2010 (in thousands):
1394922_12_ITEM8_P145_S0	The following disclosure of the estimated fair value of financial instruments is made in accordance with the guidance provided by the Financial Instruments Topic of the FASB Accounting Standards Codification.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P145_S1	Fair value estimates, methods and assumptions, set forth below for the Company s financial instruments, are made solely to comply with the requirements of the Financial Instruments Topic and should be read in conjunction with the Company s financial statements and related notes.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P146_S0	The Company has determined the estimated fair value amounts by using market information and valuation methodologies that it considers appropriate and consistent with the fair value accounting guidance.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P146_S1	Considerable judgment is required to interpret market data to develop the estimates of fair value.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P146_S2	The use of different market assumptions and/or estimation methodologies may have a material effect on the estimated fair value amounts.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P147_S0	The recorded amounts of the Company s cash and cash equivalents approximate fair value because of the liquidity and short-term maturity of these instruments.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P148_S0	The fair value of the Company s notes receivable is estimated using discounted cash flow analyses, based upon current market rates for similar types of lending arrangements, with adjustments for non-accrual loans as deemed necessary.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P149_S0	The Company s investment securities are not registered for public sale and are carried at cost which management believes approximates fair value, as appropriately adjusted for impairment.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P150_S0	The fair value of the Company s non-recourse debt is estimated using discounted cash flow analyses, based upon the current market borrowing rates for similar types of borrowing arrangements.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P151_S0	Management has determined that no recognition for the fair value of the Company s loan commitments is necessary because their terms are made on a market rate basis and require borrowers to be in compliance with the Company s credit requirements at the time of funding.
1394922_12_ITEM8_P152_S0	The fair value of contingent liabilities (or guarantees) is not considered material because management believes there has been no event that has occurred wherein a guarantee liability has been incurred or will likely be incurred.

1394922_12_ITEM9A_P0_S0	The Company s Managing Member s President and Chief Executive Officer, and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer and Chief Operating Officer ( Management ), evaluated the effectiveness of the Company s disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act Rule 13a-15(e)) as of the end of the period covered by this report.
1394922_12_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Based on the evaluation of the Company s disclosure controls and procedures, Management concluded that as of the end of the period covered by this report, the design and operation of these disclosure controls and procedures were effective.
1394922_12_ITEM9A_P1_S0	The Company does not control the financial reporting process, and is solely dependent on the Management of the Managing Member, who is responsible for providing the Company with financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States.
1394922_12_ITEM9A_P2_S0	is recorded, processed, summarized and reported, within the time periods specified in the Commission s rules and forms.
1394922_12_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Disclosure controls and procedures include, without limitation, controls and procedures designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed by an issuer in the reports that it files or submits under the Act is accumulated and communicated to the issuer s management, including its principal executive and principal financial officers, or persons performing similar functions, as appropriate to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
1394922_12_ITEM9A_P3_S0	The Management of the Managing Member is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as that term is defined in Exchange Act Rule 13a-15(f) for the Company, and for performing an assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2011.
1394922_12_ITEM9A_P3_S1	The internal control process of the Managing Member, as it is applicable to the Company, was designed to provide reasonable assurance to Management regarding the preparation and fair presentation of published financial statements, and includes those policies and procedures that:
1394922_12_ITEM9A_P4_S0	Provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of the Company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1394922_12_ITEM9A_P5_S0	All internal control processes, no matter how well designed, have inherent limitations.
1394922_12_ITEM9A_P5_S1	Therefore, even those processes determined to be effective can provide only reasonable assurance with respect to the reliability of financial statement preparation and presentation.
1394922_12_ITEM9A_P5_S2	Further, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1394922_12_ITEM9A_P6_S0	Management of the Managing Member assessed the effectiveness of its internal control over financial reporting, as it is applicable to the Company, as of December 31, 2011.
1394922_12_ITEM9A_P6_S1	In making this assessment, it used the criteria set forth in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
1394922_12_ITEM9A_P6_S2	Based on its assessment, Management of the Managing Member concluded that the Managing Member s internal control over financial reporting, as it is applicable to the Company, was effective as of December 31, 2011.
1394922_12_ITEM9A_P7_S0	This annual report does not include an attestation report of the Company s independent registered public accounting firm regarding internal control over financial reporting.
1394922_12_ITEM9A_P7_S1	Management s report was not subject to attestation by the Company s independent registered public accounting firm pursuant to Section 989G of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act, which exempts non-accelerated filers from Section 404(b) of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002.
1394922_12_ITEM9A_P8_S0	There were no changes in the Managing Member s internal control over financial reporting, as it is applicable to the Company, during the quarter ended December 31, 2011 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, the Managing Member s internal control over financial reporting, as it is applicable to the Company.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P0_S0	The registrant is a Limited Liability Company and has no officers or directors.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P1_S0	ATEL Associates 12, LLC (the Managing Member or Manager ) is the Company s Managing Member.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P1_S1	The Managing Member is controlled by ATEL Financial Services, Inc. ( AFS ), a wholly-owned subsidiary of ATEL Capital Group ( ACG or ATEL ).
1394922_12_ITEM10_P1_S2	The outstanding voting capital stock of ATEL is owned 100% by Dean L. Cash.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P2_S0	Each of AFS and ATEL Leasing Corporation ( ALC ) is a wholly-owned subsidiary of ACG and performs services for the Company on behalf of the Managing Member.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P2_S1	Acquisition services, equipment management, lease administration and asset disposition services are performed by ALC; investor relations and communications services, and general administrative services are performed by AFS.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P3_S0	The officers and directors of ACG and its affiliates are as follows:
1394922_12_ITEM10_P4_S0	Dean L. Cash, age 61, became chairman, president and chief executive officer of ATEL in April 2001.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P4_S1	Mr. Cash joined ATEL as director of marketing in 1980 and served as a vice president since 1981, executive vice president since 1983 and a director since 1984.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P4_S2	Prior to joining ATEL, Mr. Cash was a senior marketing representative for Martin Marietta Corporation, data systems division, from 1979 to 1980.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P4_S3	From 1977 to 1979, he was employed by General Electric Corporation, where he was an applications specialist in the medical systems division and a marketing representative in the information services division.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P5_S0	Mr. Cash was a systems engineer with Electronic Data Systems from 1975 to 1977, and was involved in maintaining and developing software for commercial applications.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P5_S1	Mr. Cash received a B.S. degree in psychology and mathematics in 1972 and an M.B.A. degree with a concentration in finance in 1975 from Florida State University.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P5_S2	Mr. Cash is an arbitrator with the American Arbitration Association and is qualified as a registered principal with the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P6_S0	Paritosh K. Choksi, age 58, joined ATEL in 1999 as a director, senior vice president and its chief financial officer.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P6_S1	He became its executive vice president and CFO/COO in April 2001.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P6_S2	Prior to joining ATEL, Mr. Choksi was chief financial officer at Wink Communications, Inc. from 1997 to 1999.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P6_S3	From 1977 to 1997, Mr. Choksi was with Phoenix American Incorporated, a financial services and management company, where he held various positions during his tenure, and was senior vice president, chief financial officer and director when he left the company.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P6_S4	Mr. Choksi was involved in all corporate matters at Phoenix and was responsible for Phoenix s capital market needs.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P6_S5	He also served on the credit committee overseeing all corporate investments, including its venture lease portfolio.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P6_S6	Mr. Choksi was a part of the executive management team which caused Phoenix s portfolio to increase from $50 million in assets to over $2 billion.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P6_S7	Mr. Choksi is a member of the board of directors of Syntel, Inc.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P7_S0	Mr. Choksi received a bachelor of technology degree in mechanical engineering from the Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay; and an M.B.A. degree from the University of California, Berkeley.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P8_S0	Vasco H. Morais, age 53, joined ATEL in 1989 as general counsel.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P8_S1	Mr. Morais manages ATEL s legal department, which provides legal and contractual support in the negotiating, documenting, drafting, reviewing and funding of lease transactions.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P8_S2	In addition, Mr. Morais advises on general corporate law matters, and assists on securities law issues.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P9_S0	From 1986 to 1989, Mr. Morais was employed by the BankAmeriLease Companies, Bank of America s equipment leasing subsidiaries, providing in-house legal support on the documentation of tax-oriented and non-tax oriented direct and leveraged lease transactions, vendor leasing programs and general corporate matters.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P9_S1	Prior to the BankAmeriLease Companies, Mr. Morais was with the Consolidated Capital Companies in the Corporate and Securities Legal Department involved in drafting and reviewing contracts, advising on corporate law matters and securities law issues.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P10_S0	Golden Gate University Law School; and an M.B.A. (Finance) degree from Golden Gate University in 1997.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P10_S1	Mr. Morais, an active member of the State Bar of California since 1986, served as co-chair of the Uniform Business Law Section of the State Bar of California and was inducted as a fellow of the American College of Commercial Finance Lawyers in 2010.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P11_S0	The board of directors of the Managing Member acts as the audit committee of the Company.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P11_S1	Dean L. Cash and Paritosh K. Choksi are members of the board of directors of the Managing Member and are deemed to be financial experts.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P11_S2	They are not independent of the Company.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P12_S0	Based solely on a review of Forms 3, 4, and 5, the Company is not aware of any failures to file reports of beneficial ownership required to be filed during or for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1394922_12_ITEM10_P13_S0	A Code of Ethics that is applicable to the Company, including the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer and Chief Operating Officer of its Manager, ATEL Associates 12, LLC, or persons acting in such capacity on behalf of the Company, is included as Exhibit 14.1 to this report.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P0_S0	The registrant has no officers or directors.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P1_S0	Set forth hereinafter is a description of the nature of remuneration paid and to be paid to the Manager and its affiliates.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P1_S1	The amount of such remuneration paid for the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010 is set forth in Item 8 of this report under the caption Financial Statements and Supplementary Data Notes to Financial Statements Related party transactions, at Note 7 thereof, which information is hereby incorporated by reference.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P2_S0	The Company paid selling commissions in the amount of 9% of Gross Proceeds, as defined, to ATEL Securities Corporation, an affiliate of the Manager.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P3_S0	Through December 31, 2009, $2.7 million of such commissions had either been accrued or paid to ASC.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P3_S1	Of that amount, $2.3 million has been re-allowed to other broker/dealers.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P3_S2	The Company did not incur any additional selling commissions subsequent to December 31, 2009.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P4_S0	The Company pays the Manager an Asset Management Fee in an amount equal to 4% of Operating Revenues, which includes Gross Lease Revenues and Cash from Sales or Refinancing.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P4_S1	The Asset Management Fee is paid on a monthly basis.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P4_S2	The amount of the Asset Management Fee payable in any year is reduced for that year to the extent it would otherwise exceed the Asset Management Fee Limit, as described below.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P5_S0	The Asset Management Fee is paid for services rendered by the Manager and its affiliates in determining portfolio and investment strategies and generally managing or supervising the management of the investment portfolio.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P6_S0	The Manager also receives, as its Carried Interest, an amount equal to 7.5% of all Company Distributions.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P7_S0	AFS supervises performance of all management activities, including, among other activities: the acquisition and financing of the investment portfolio, collection of lease and loan revenues, monitoring compliance by lessees/borrowers with their contract terms, assuring that investment assets are being used in accordance with all operative contractual arrangements, paying operating expenses and arranging for necessary maintenance and repair of equipment and property in the event a lessee fails to do so, monitoring property, sales and use tax compliance and preparation of operating financial data.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P7_S1	AFS intends to delegate all or a portion of its duties and the Asset Management Fee to one or more of its affiliates who are in the business of providing such services.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P8_S0	The Fund has adopted a single Asset Management Fee plus the Carried Interest as a means of compensating the Manager for sponsoring the Fund and managing its operations.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P8_S1	While this compensation structure is intended to simplify management compensation for purposes of investor s understanding, state securities administrators use a more complicated compensation structure in their review of equipment program offerings in order to assure that those offerings are fair under the states merit review guidelines.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P8_S2	The total of all Front End Fees, the Carried Interest and the Asset Management Fee will be subject to the Asset Management Fee Limit in order to assure these state administrators that the Fund will not bear greater fees than permitted under the state merit review guidelines.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P9_S0	The North American Securities Administrators Association, Inc. ( NASAA ) is an organization of state securities administrators, those state government agencies responsible for qualifying securities offerings in their respective states.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P9_S1	NASAA has established standards for the qualification of a number of different types of securities offerings and investment products, including its Statement of Policy on Equipment Programs (the NASAA Equipment Leasing Guidelines ).
1394922_12_ITEM11_P9_S2	Article IV, Sections C through G of the NASAA Equipment Leasing Guidelines establish the standards for payment of reasonable carried interests, promotional interests and fees for equipment acquisition, management, resale and releasing services to equipment leasing program sponsors.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P9_S3	Article IV, Sections C through G of the NASAA Equipment Leasing Guidelines set the maximum compensation payable to the sponsor and its affiliates from an equipment leasing program such as the Fund.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P9_S4	The Asset Management Fee Limit will equal the maximum compensation payable under Article IV, Sections C through G of the NASAA Equipment Leasing Guidelines as in effect on the date of the Fund s prospectus (the NASAA Fee Limitation ).
1394922_12_ITEM11_P9_S5	Under the Asset Management Fee Limit, the Fund will calculate the maximum fees payable under the NASAA Fee Limitation and guarantee that the Asset Management Fee it will pay the Manager and its Affiliates, when added to its Carried Interest, will never exceed the fees and interests payable to a sponsor and its affiliates under the NASAA Fee Limitation.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P10_S0	The Asset Management Fee Limit will be calculated each year during the Fund s term by calculating the total fees that would be paid to the Manager if the Manager were to be compensated on the basis of the maximum compensation payable under the NASAA Fee Limitation, including the Manager s Carried Interest, as described below.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P10_S1	To the extent that the amount paid as Front End Fees, the Asset Management Fee, and the Carried Interest for any year would cause the total fees to exceed the aggregate amount of fees calculated under the NASAA Fee Limitation for the year, the Asset Management Fee and/or Carried Interest for that year will be reduced to equal the maximum aggregate fees under the NASAA Fee Limitation.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P10_S2	To the extent any such fees are reduced, the amount of such reduction will be accrued and deferred, and such accrued and deferred compensation would be paid to the Manager in a subsequent period, but only to the extent that the deferred compensation would be within the Asset Management Fee Limit for that later period.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P10_S3	Any deferred fees that cannot be paid under the applicable limitations through the date of liquidation would be forfeited by the Manager at liquidation.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P11_S0	Under the NASAA Equipment Leasing Guidelines, the Fund is required to commit a minimum percentage of the Gross Proceeds to Investment in Equipment, calculated as the greater of: (i) 80% of the Gross Proceeds reduced by 0.0625% for each 1% of indebtedness encumbering the Fund s equipment; or (ii) 75% of such Gross Proceeds.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P11_S1	The Fund intends to incur total indebtedness equal to 50% of the aggregate cost of its equipment.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P11_S2	The Operating Agreement requires the Fund to commit at least 85.875% of the Gross Proceeds to Investment in Equipment.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P11_S3	[50% x .0625%] = 76.875%), and the Fund s minimum Investment in Equipment would therefore exceed the NASAA Fee Limitation minimum by 9%.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P12_S0	The amount of the Carried Interest permitted the Manager under the NASAA Fee Limitation will be dependent on the amount by which the percentage of Gross Proceeds the Fund ultimately commits to Investment in Equipment exceeds the minimum Investment in Equipment under the NASAA Fee Limitation.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P12_S1	The NASAA Fee Limitation permits the Manager and its Affiliates to receive compensation in the form of a carried interest in Fund Net Income, Net Loss and Distributions equal to 1% for the first 2.5% of excess Investment in Equipment over the NASAA Guidelines minimum, 1% for the next 2% of such excess, and 1% for each additional 1% of excess Investment in Equipment.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P12_S2	With a minimum Investment in Equipment of 85.875%, the Manager and its Affiliates may receive an additional carried interest equal to 6.5% of Net Profit, Net Loss and Distributions under the foregoing formula (2.5% + 2% + 4.5% = 9%; 1% + 1% + 4.5% = 6.5%).
1394922_12_ITEM11_P12_S3	At the lowest permitted level of Investment in Equipment, the NASAA Guidelines would permit the Manager and its Affiliates to receive a promotional interest equal to 5% of Distributions of Cash from Operations and 1% of Distributions of Sale or Refinancing Proceeds until Members have received total Distributions equal to their Original Invested Capital plus an 8% per annum cumulative return on their Adjusted Invested Capital, and, thereafter, the promotional interest may increase to 15% of all Distributions.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P13_S0	With the additional carried interest calculated as described above, the maximum aggregate fees payable to the Manager and Affiliates under the NASAA Guidelines as carried interest and promotional interest would equal 11.5% of Distributions of Cash from Operations (6.5% + 5% = 11.5%), and 7.5% of Distributions of Sale or Refinancing Proceeds (6.5% + 1% = 7.5%), before the subordination level was reached, and 21.5% of all Distributions thereafter.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P13_S1	The maximum amounts to be paid under the terms of the Operating Agreement are subject to the application of the Asset Management Fee Limit provided in Section 8.3 of the Agreement, which limits the annual amount payable to the Manager and its Affiliates as the Asset Management Fee and the Carried Interest to an aggregate not to exceed the total amount of fees that would be payable to the Manager and its Affiliates under the NASAA Fee Limitation.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P14_S0	Upon completion of the offering of Units, final commitment of offering proceeds to acquisition of equipment and establishment of final levels of permanent portfolio debt, the Manager will calculate the maximum carried interest and promotional interest payable to the Manager and its Affiliates under the NASAA Fee Limitation and compare such total permitted fees to the total of the Asset Management Fee and Manager s Carried Interest.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P14_S1	If and to the extent that the Asset Management Fee and Manager s Carried Interest would exceed the fees calculated under the NASAA Fee Limitation, the fees payable to the Manager and its Affiliates will be reduced by an amount sufficient to cause the total of such compensation to comply with the NASAA Fee Limitation.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P14_S2	The adjusted Asset Management Fee Limit will then be applied to the Asset Management Fee and Carried Interest as described above.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P14_S3	A comparison of the Front End Fees actually paid by the Fund and the NASAA Fee Limitation maximums will be repeated, and any required adjustments will be made, at least annually thereafter.
1394922_12_ITEM11_P15_S0	See Note 7 to the financial statements as set forth in Part II, Item 8, Financial Statements and Supplementary Data, for amounts paid.
1394922_12_ITEM12_P0_S0	At December 31, 2011, no investor is known to hold beneficially more than 5% of the issued and outstanding Units.
1394922_12_ITEM12_P1_S0	The parent of ATEL Associates 12, LLC is the beneficial owner of Limited Liability Company Units as follows:
1394922_12_ITEM13_P0_S0	See Item 8 of this report under the caption Financial Statements and Supplementary Data Notes to Financial Statements Related party transactions at Note 7 thereof.
1394922_12_ITEM14_P0_S0	During the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010, the Company incurred audit, audit related and other fees with its principal auditors as follows (in thousands):
1394922_12_ITEM14_P1_S0	Audit fees consist of the aggregate fees and expenses billed in connection with the audit of the Company s annual financial statements and the review of the financial statements included in the Company s quarterly reports on Form 10-Q.
1394922_12_ITEM14_P2_S0	Other fees represent costs incurred in connection with various Agreed-Upon Procedures engagements.
1394922_12_ITEM14_P3_S0	The board of directors of the Managing Member acts as the audit committee of the registrant.
1394922_12_ITEM14_P3_S1	Engagements for audit services, audit related services and tax services are approved in advance by the Chief Financial Officer of the Managing Member acting on behalf of the board of directors of the Managing Member in its role as the audit committee of the Company.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P0_S0	Included in Part II of this report:
1394922_12_ITEM15_P1_S0	All schedules for which provision is made in the applicable accounting regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission are not required under the related instructions or are inapplicable and, therefore, have been omitted.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P2_S0	Pursuant to the requirements of Section 13 or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, the registrant has duly caused this report to be signed on its behalf by the undersigned, thereunto duly authorized.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P3_S0	Pursuant to the requirements of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, this report has been signed below by the persons in the capacities and on the dates indicated.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P4_S0	No proxy materials have been or will be sent to security holders.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P5_S0	An annual report will be furnished to security holders subsequent to the filing of this report on Form 10-K, and copies thereof will be furnished supplementally to the Commission when forwarded to the security holders.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P6_S0	This Code of Ethics is applicable to ATEL 12, LLC ( Fund 12 ), including the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer and Chief Operating Officer of its Manager, ATEL Associates 12, LLC ( AA12 ), or persons acting in such capacity (collectively the Covered Officers ) on behalf of Fund 12, referred to herein as the Company.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P7_S0	Accordingly, under the Securities and Exchange Commission s interpretation of its disclosure rules, the Board of Directors of the Manager of AA12, ATEL Financial Services, LLC ( AFS ), functions as the de facto audit committee for the Company with respect to all procedural and disclosure requirements applicable to audit committees under Securities and Exchange Commission rules.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P7_S1	The Board of Directors shall have oversight responsibility over the activities of the Company for purposes of this Code of Ethics.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P8_S0	The Company is proud of the values with which it conducts business.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P8_S1	It has and will continue to uphold the highest levels of business ethics and personal integrity in all types of transactions and interactions.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P8_S2	To this end, this Code of Ethics serves to (1) emphasize the Company s commitment to ethics and compliance with the law; (2) set forth basic standards of ethical and legal behavior; (3) provide reporting mechanisms for known or suspected ethical or legal violations; and (4) help prevent and detect wrongdoing.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P8_S3	This Code of Ethics is intended to augment and supplement the standard of ethics and business conduct expected of all Company employees, and its limitation to Covered Officers is not intended to limit the obligation of all Company employees to adhere to the highest standards of business ethics and integrity in all transactions and interactions conducted while in the Company s employ.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P9_S0	Given the variety and complexity of ethical questions that may arise in the course of business of the Company, this Code of Ethics serves only as a rough guide.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P9_S1	Confronted with ethically ambiguous situations, the Covered Officers should remember the Company s commitment to the highest ethical standards and seek independent advice, where necessary, to ensure that all actions they take on behalf of the Company honor this commitment.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P10_S0	The Covered Officers shall behave honestly and ethically at all times and with all people.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P10_S1	They shall act in good faith, with due care, and shall engage only in fair and open competition, by treating ethically competitors, suppliers, customers, and colleagues.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P10_S2	They shall not misrepresent facts or engage in illegal, unethical, or anti-competitive practices for personal or professional gain.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P11_S0	This fundamental standard of honest and ethical conduct extends to the handling of conflicts of interest.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P11_S1	The Covered Officers shall avoid any actual, potential, or apparent conflicts of interest with the Company, and any personal activities, investments, or associations that might give rise to such conflicts.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P11_S2	They shall not compete with or use the Company, for personal gain, self-deal, or take advantage of any corporate opportunities.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P11_S3	They shall act on behalf of the Company free from improper influence or the appearance of improper influence on their judgment or performance of duties.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P11_S4	A Covered Officer shall disclose any material transaction or relationship that reasonably could be expected to give rise to such a conflict to the Company s General Counsel or a member of the Company s Board of Directors.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P11_S5	No action may be taken with respect to such transaction or party unless and until the Company s Board of Directors has approved such action.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P12_S0	Notwithstanding the foregoing, it is understood, as fully disclosed in the offering documents for the Company, that AA12 as managing member of the Company has certain inherent conflicts of interest.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P12_S1	The provisions of the Company s Operating Agreement have been drafted to address the obligations, restrictions and limitations on the power and authority of AA12 to manage the Company s affairs, including restrictions prohibiting or limiting the terms of any transactions in which conflicts of interest may arise.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P12_S2	Furthermore, AFS has a fiduciary duty to the Company as its manager.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P12_S3	It is therefore expressly understood by the Company and the Covered Officers that any and all actions by AA12 and its personnel that comply with the provisions of the Company s Operating Agreement, and which are consistent with AA12 s fiduciary duty to the Company, will not be considered material transactions or relationships which require disclosure or reporting under this Code of Ethics.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P13_S0	In reports and documents filed with or submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission and other regulators by the Company and in other public communications made by the Company, the Covered Officers shall make disclosures that are full, fair, accurate, timely, and understandable.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P13_S1	The Covered Officers shall provide thorough and accurate financial and accounting data for inclusion in such disclosures.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P13_S2	The Covered Officers shall not knowingly conceal or falsify information, misrepresent material facts, or omit material facts necessary to avoid misleading the Company s independent public auditors or investors.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P14_S0	In conducting the business of the Company, the Covered Officers shall comply with applicable governmental laws, rules, and regulations at all levels of government in the United States and in any non-U.S. jurisdiction in which the Company does business, as well as applicable rules and regulations of self-regulatory organizations of which the Company is a member.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P14_S1	If the Covered Officer is unsure whether a particular action would violate an applicable law, rule, or regulation, he or she should seek the advice of inside counsel (if available), and, where necessary, outside counsel before undertaking it.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P15_S0	The Covered Officers will promptly bring to the attention of the Company s General Counsel or the Board of Directors any information concerning a material violation of any of the laws, rules or regulations applicable to the Company and the operation of its businesses, by the Company or any agent thereof, or of violation of this Code of Ethics.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P15_S1	The Company s General Counsel will investigate reports of violations and the findings communicated to the Company s Board of Directors.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P16_S0	If the Company s Board of Directors determines that this Code of Ethics has been violated, either directly, by failure to report a violation, or by withholding information related to a violation, it may discipline the offending Covered Officer for non-compliance with penalties up to and including termination of employment.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P16_S1	Violations of this Code of Ethics may also constitute violations of law and may result in criminal penalties and civil liabilities for the offending Covered Officer and the Company.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P17_S0	I, Dean L. Cash, certify that:
1394922_12_ITEM15_P18_S0	The registrant s other certifying officer(s) and I are responsible for establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e)) and internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f)) for the registrant and have:
1394922_12_ITEM15_P19_S0	The registrant s other certifying officer(s) and I have disclosed, based on our most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the registrant s auditors and the audit committee of the registrant s board of directors (or persons performing the equivalent functions):
1394922_12_ITEM15_P20_S0	Any fraud, whether or not material, that involves management or other employees who have a significant role in the registrant s internal control over financial reporting.
1394922_12_ITEM15_P21_S0	I, Paritosh K. Choksi, certify that:
1394922_12_ITEM15_P22_S0	The registrant s other certifying officer(s) and I are responsible for establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e)) and internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f)) for the registrant and have:
1394922_12_ITEM15_P23_S0	The registrant s other certifying officer(s) and I have disclosed, based on our most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the registrant s auditors and the audit committee of the registrant s board of directors (or persons performing the equivalent functions):
1394922_12_ITEM15_P24_S0	Any fraud, whether or not material, that involves management or other employees who have a significant role in the registrant s internal control over financial reporting.

1394922_13_ITEM1_P0_S0	ATEL 12, LLC (the Company or the Fund ) was formed under the laws of the state of California on January 25, 2007 for the purpose of equipment financing and acquiring equipment to engage in equipment leasing and sales activities, as well as in real estate, growth capital investment activities and green technologies (the principal operations ).
1394922_13_ITEM1_P0_S1	The Managing Member of the Company is ATEL Associates 12, LLC (the Managing Member ), a Nevada limited liability company.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P0_S2	The Fund may continue until December 31, 2030.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P1_S0	As a limited liability company, the liability of any individual member for the obligations of the Fund is limited to the extent of capital contributions to the Fund by the individual member.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P2_S0	The Company conducted a public offering of 20,000,000 Limited Liability Company Units ( Units ), at a price of $10 per Unit.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P2_S1	On January 24, 2008, subscriptions for the minimum number of Units (120,000, representing $1.2 million), excluding subscriptions from Pennsylvania investors, had been received and the Fund requested subscription proceeds to be released from escrow.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P2_S2	On that date, the Company commenced initial operations and continued in its development stage activities until transitioning to an operating enterprise during the second quarter of 2008.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P3_S0	Pennsylvania subscriptions were subject to a separate escrow to be released to the Fund only when the Fund had received aggregate subscriptions for all investors equal to at least $7.5 million.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P3_S1	Total contributions to the Fund exceeded $7.5 million on July 15, 2008.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P3_S2	The offering was terminated on September 25, 2009.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P4_S0	As of December 31, 2012, cumulative contributions, net of rescissions and repurchases, totaling $29.9 million (inclusive of the $500 initial member s capital investment) have been received and 2,993,482 Units were issued and outstanding.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P5_S0	The Fund, or Managing Member and/or affiliates on behalf of the Fund, has incurred costs in connection with the organization, registration and issuance of the limited liability company units (Units).
1394922_13_ITEM1_P5_S1	The amount of such costs to be borne by the Fund is limited by certain provisions of the ATEL 12, LLC Limited Liability Company Operating Agreement dated April 3, 2007 (the Operating Agreement ).
1394922_13_ITEM1_P6_S0	The Company s principal objectives are to invest in a diversified portfolio of investments that (i) preserves, protects and returns the Company s invested capital; (ii) generates regular cash distributions to Unitholders, any balance remaining after required minimum distributions to be used to purchase additional investments during the reinvestment period ( Reinvestment Period ) (defined as six full years following the year the offering was terminated) which ends on December 31, 2015 and (iii) provides additional cash distributions following the Reinvestment Period and until all investment portfolio assets have been sold or otherwise disposed.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P6_S1	The Company is governed by its Operating Agreement, as amended.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P7_S0	The Company has acquired and intends to acquire various types of new and used equipment subject to leases and to make loans secured by equipment acquired by its borrowers.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P7_S1	The Company s primary investment objective is to acquire investments primarily in low-technology, low-obsolescence equipment such as materials handling equipment, manufacturing equipment, mining equipment, and transportation equipment.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P7_S2	A portion of the portfolio will include some more technology-dependent equipment such as certain types of communications equipment, medical equipment, manufacturing equipment and office equipment.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P7_S3	The Company will also seek investments in equipment or financing of equipment and business involving green technologies such as those involved in the following activities: materials recycling, water purification, sewage treatment pollution radiation, gas and other emission treatment, solid waste management, renewable energy generation, as well as many other similar industries and activities.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P8_S0	The Company only purchases equipment under pre-existing leases or for which a lease will be entered into concurrently at the time of the purchase.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P8_S1	Through December 31, 2012, the Company had purchased equipment with a total acquisition price of $27.7 million.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P8_S2	The Company had also loaned $4.5 million for notes receivable secured by various assets.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P9_S0	The Company s objective is to have at least 60% of its investment portfolio (by cost) consist of equipment leased to lessees that the Manager deems to be high quality corporate credits and/or leases guaranteed by such high quality corporate credits.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P10_S0	with histories of profitability or municipalities.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P10_S1	The remaining 40% of the initial investment portfolio may include equipment lease transactions, real property single tenant net leases and other financing for companies which, although deemed creditworthy by the Manager, would not satisfy the specific credit criteria for the portfolio described above.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P10_S2	Included in this 40% of the portfolio may be growth capital financing investments.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P10_S3	No more than 20% of the initial portfolio, by cost, will consist of these growth capital financing investments and no more than 20% of the portfolio, by cost, will consist of real estate investments.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P10_S4	The Company s objective is to invest approximately 25% of its capital in assets that involve green technologies or applications as discussed above.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P11_S0	During 2012 and 2011, certain lessees generated significant portions (defined as 10% or more) of the Company s total leasing and lending revenues as follows:
1394922_13_ITEM1_P12_S0	These percentages are not expected to be comparable in future periods.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P13_S0	The equipment financing industry is highly competitive.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P13_S1	Equipment manufacturers, corporations, partnerships and others offer users an alternative to the purchase of most types of equipment with payment terms that vary widely depending on the type of financing, the lease or loan term and type of equipment.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P13_S2	The ability of the Company to keep the equipment leased and the terms of purchase, lease and sale of equipment depends on various factors (many of which neither the Managing Member nor the Company can control), such as general economic conditions, including the effects of inflation or recession, and fluctuations in supply and demand for various types of equipment resulting from, among other things, technological and economic obsolescence.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P14_S0	The Managing Member will seek to limit the amount invested in equipment or property leased to any single lessee to not more than 20% of the aggregate purchase price of investments owned at any time during the reinvestment period; (ii) in no event will the Company s equity investment in equipment or property leased to a single lessee exceed an amount equal to 20% of the maximum capital from the sale of Units (or $30 million); and (iii) the Managing Member will seek to invest not more than 20% of the aggregate purchase price of equipment in equipment acquired from a single manufacturer.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P14_S1	However, this last limitation is a general guideline only, and the Company may acquire equipment from a single manufacturer in excess of the stated percentage during the offering period and before the offering proceeds are fully invested, or if the Managing Member deems such a course of action to be in the Company s best interest.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P15_S0	The primary geographic regions in which the Company seeks leasing opportunities are North America and Europe.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P15_S1	Currently, 100% of the Company s operating revenues are from customers domiciled in North America.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P16_S0	The business of the Company is not seasonal.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P17_S0	The Company has no full time employees.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P17_S1	Employees of the Managing Member and affiliates provide the services the Company requires to effectively operate.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P17_S2	The cost of these services is reimbursed by the Company to the Managing Member and affiliates per the Operating Agreement.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P18_S0	The Company has acquired a diversified portfolio of equipment.
1394922_13_ITEM1_P18_S1	The equipment has been leased to lessees in various industries.

1394922_13_ITEM2_P0_S0	The Company does not own or lease any real property, plant or material physical properties other than the equipment held for lease as set forth in Item 1, Business.
1394922_13_ITEM3_P0_S0	In the ordinary course of conducting business, there may be certain claims, suits, and complaints filed against the Company.
1394922_13_ITEM3_P0_S1	In the opinion of management, the outcome of such matters, if any, will not have a material impact on the Company s financial position or results of operations.
1394922_13_ITEM3_P0_S2	No material legal proceedings are currently pending against the Company or against any of its assets.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P0_S0	There are certain material conditions and restrictions on the transfer of Units imposed by the terms of the Operating Agreement.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P0_S1	Consequently, there is no public market for Units and it is not anticipated that a public market for Units will develop.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P0_S2	In the absence of a public market for the Units, there is no currently ascertainable fair market value for the Units.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P1_S0	As of December 31, 2012, a total of 905 investors were Unitholders of record in the Company.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P2_S0	As noted above, there is no public market for Units and, in order to preserve the Company s status for federal income tax purposes, the Company will not permit a secondary market or the substantial equivalent of a secondary market for the Units.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P2_S1	In the absence of a public market for the Units, there is no currently ascertainable fair market value for the Units.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P3_S0	Nevertheless, in order to provide an estimated per Unit value for those Unitholders who seek valuation information, the Manager has calculated an estimated value per Unit as of December 31, 2012.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P4_S0	The Manager estimates the Company s per Unit value by first estimating the aggregate net asset value of the Company.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P4_S1	The valuation does not take into account any future business activity of the Company; rather it is a snapshot view of the Fund s portfolio as of the valuation date.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P5_S0	The estimated values for non-interest bearing items such as any current assets and liabilities, as well as for any investment in securities, were assumed to equal their reported balances, which management believes approximate their fair values, as adjusted for impairment.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P5_S1	The same was applied to loans incurred under the acquisition facility since they bear variable rates of interest.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P6_S0	A discounted cash flow approach was used to estimate the values of notes receivable, investments in leases and non-recourse debt.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P6_S1	Under such approach, the value of a financial instrument was estimated by calculating the present value of the instrument s expected cash flows.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P6_S2	The present value was determined by discounting the cash flows the instrument is expected to generate by discount rates as deemed appropriate by the Manager.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P6_S3	In most cases, the discount rates used were based on U.S. Treasury yields reported as of the reporting date, plus a spread to account for the credit risk difference between the instrument being valued and Treasury securities.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P7_S0	After calculating the aggregate estimated net asset value of the Company, the Manager then calculated the portion of the aggregate estimated value that would be distributed to Unitholders on liquidation of the Company, and divided the total that would be so distributable by the number of outstanding Units as of the December 31, 2012 valuation date.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P7_S1	As of December 31, 2012, the value of the Company s assets, calculated on this basis, was approximately $9.04 per Unit.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P8_S0	The foregoing valuation was performed solely for the purpose of providing an estimated liquidation value per Unit for those Unitholders who seek valuation information.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P8_S1	It is important to note again that there is no market for the Units, and, accordingly, this value does not represent an estimate of the amount a Unitholder would receive if he were to seek to sell his Units.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P9_S0	The Company will liquidate its assets in the ordinary course of its business and investment cycle.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P9_S1	Furthermore, there can be no assurance as to when the Company will be fully liquidated, the amount the Company may actually receive if and when it seeks to liquidate its assets, the amount of lease payments and equipment disposition proceeds the Company will actually receive over the remaining term of the Company, or the amounts that may actually be received in distributions by Unitholders over the course of the Company s remaining term.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P10_S0	The Unitholders of record are entitled to certain distributions as provided under the Operating Agreement.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P11_S0	federal income tax bracket to meet the federal and state income taxes due on income from the operations of the Fund; (ii) through the first full fiscal quarter ending at least six months after termination of the offering of Units, an amount equal to the lesser of: (a) a rate of return on their original capital contribution equal to 2.5% over the average yield on five-year United States Treasury Bonds for the fiscal quarter immediately preceding the date of distribution, as published in a national financial newspaper from time to time (with a minimum of 8% per annum and a maximum of 9% per annum), or (b) 90% of the total amount of cash available for distributions; and (iii) for each quarter during the rest of the reinvestment period, an amount equal to 9% per annum on their original capital contribution.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P12_S0	The Company commenced periodic distributions in February 2008.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P12_S1	The rate for monthly distributions from 2012 operations was $0.075 per Unit for the period from January through December 2012.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P12_S2	Likewise the rate for monthly distributions from 2011 operations was $0.075 per Unit for the period from January through December 2011.
1394922_13_ITEM5_P12_S3	The rate for each of the quarterly distributions paid in 2012 and 2011 was $0.225 per Unit.
