1394922_13_ITEM6_P0_S0	A smaller reporting company is not required to present selected financial data in accordance with item 301(c) of Regulation S-K.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P0_S0	Statements contained in this Item 7, Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations ( MD A ) and elsewhere in this Form 10-K, which are not historical facts, may be forward-looking statements.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P0_S1	Such statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P0_S2	In particular, economic recession and changes in general economic conditions, including fluctuations in demand for equipment, lease rates, and interest rates, may result in delays in investment and reinvestment, delays in leasing, re-leasing, and disposition of equipment, and reduced returns on invested capital.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P0_S3	The Company s performance is subject to risks relating to lessee defaults and the creditworthiness of its lessees.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P0_S4	The Company s performance is also subject to risks relating to the value of its equipment at the end of its leases, which may be affected by the condition of the equipment, technological obsolescence and the markets for new and used equipment at the end of lease terms.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P1_S0	Investors are cautioned not to attribute undue certainty to these forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date of this Form 10-K. We undertake no obligation to publicly release any revisions to these forward-looking statements to reflect events or circumstances after the date of this Form 10-K or to reflect the occurrence of unanticipated events, other than as required by law.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P2_S0	ATEL 12, LLC (the Company or the Fund ) is a California limited liability company that was formed in January 2007 for the purpose of equipment financing and acquiring equipment to engage in equipment leasing and sales activities, as well as in real estate, growth capital investment activities and green technologies (the principal operations ), primarily in the United States.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P3_S0	The Company conducted a public offering of 20,000,000 Limited Liability Company Units ( Units ), at a price of $10 per Unit.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P3_S1	On January 24, 2008, subscriptions for the minimum number of Units (120,000, representing $1.2 million), excluding subscriptions from Pennsylvania investors, had been received and the Fund requested subscription proceeds to be released from escrow.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P3_S2	On that date, the Company commenced initial operations and continued in its development stage activities until transitioning to an operating enterprise during the second quarter of 2008.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P4_S0	Pennsylvania subscriptions were subject to a separate escrow to be released to the Fund only when the Fund had received aggregate subscriptions for all investors equal to at least $7.5 million.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P4_S1	Total contributions to the Fund exceeded $7.5 million on July 15, 2008.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P4_S2	As of September 25, 2009, the offering was terminated.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P5_S0	On January 29, 2008, the Fund made its first investment in a long-term operating lease.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P5_S1	As of December 31, 2012, the Company has purchased a total of $27.7 million of equipment for long-term operating and direct financing leases and funded investments in notes receivable totaling $4.5 million.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P6_S0	The Company completed its initial acquisition stage with the investment of the net proceeds from the public offering of Units.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P6_S1	Subsequently, during the reinvestment period ( Reinvestment Period ) (defined as six full years following the year the offering was terminated), the Company will reinvest cash flow in excess of certain amounts required to be distributed to the Other Members and/or utilize its credit facilities to acquire additional equipment.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P6_S2	Throughout the Reinvestment Period, which ends December 31, 2015, the Company anticipates continued reinvestment of cash flow in excess of minimum distributions and other obligations.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P7_S0	The Company is governed by its Limited Liability Company Operating Agreement ( Operating Agreement ), as amended.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P8_S0	The Company may continue until December 31, 2030.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P8_S1	Periodic distributions are paid at the discretion of the Managing Member.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P9_S0	As of December 31, 2012 and 2011, there were concentrations (greater than 10% as a percentage of total equipment cost) of equipment leased to lessees and/or financial borrowers in certain industries as follows:
1394922_13_ITEM7_P10_S0	As previously mentioned, certain lessees generated significant portions (defined as 10% or more) of the Company s total leasing and lending revenues during 2012 and 2011 as follows:
1394922_13_ITEM7_P11_S0	These percentages are not expected to be comparable in future periods due to anticipated changes in the mix of investments and/or lessees as a result of normal business activities.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P12_S0	It is the Company s objective to maintain a 100% utilization rate for all equipment purchased in any given year.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P12_S1	All equipment transactions are acquired subject to binding lease commitments, so equipment utilization is expected to remain high throughout the reinvestment stage.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P12_S2	Initial lease terms of these leases are generally from 36 to 120 months, and as they expire, the Company will attempt to re-lease or sell the equipment; as such, utilization rates may tend to decrease during the liquidation stage of the Company.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P12_S3	All of the Company s leased property was acquired during the period from 2008 to 2012.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P12_S4	The utilization percentage of existing assets under lease was 98% and 100% as of December 31, 2012 and 2011, respectively.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P13_S0	Cost reimbursements to the Managing Member are based on its costs incurred in performing administrative services for the Company.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P13_S1	These costs are allocated to each managed entity based on certain criteria such as total assets, number of investors or contributed capital based upon the type of cost incurred.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P14_S0	The Company had net income of $291 thousand and $174 thousand for the years ended December 31, 2012 and 2011, respectively.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P14_S1	Results for 2012 reflect decreases in both total operating expenses and total revenues when compared to prior year.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P15_S0	Total revenues for 2012 decreased by $568 thousand, or 11%, as compared to prior year.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P15_S1	The decrease was mostly due to a reduction in operating lease revenues which was lower by $525 thousand largely as a result of run-off and sales of lease assets.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P16_S0	Total expenses for 2012 decreased by $685 thousand, or 14%, as compared to prior year, primarily due to lower depreciation and acquisition expenses offset, in part, by increases in outside services expense and the provision for credit losses.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P17_S0	The decrease in depreciation expense totaled $684 thousand and was largely a result of run-off and sales of lease assets while the decline in acquisition expense totaled $48 thousand and was a result of the year over year decrease in lease and loan origination activity.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P18_S0	Partially offsetting the aforementioned decreases in expenses were increases in outside services expense and the provision for credit losses totaling $65 thousand and $51 thousand, respectively.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P18_S1	The increase in outside services was mainly attributable to an approximate $54 thousand third quarter 2011 reimbursement of expenses advanced to facilitate the liquidation of the asset holdings of a delinquent borrower.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P18_S2	The increase in the provision for credit losses primarily reflect $45 thousand of fair value adjustments made to notes receivable deemed impaired during 2012 coupled with an increase in the allowance relative to delinquent receivables.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P19_S0	At December 31, 2012 and 2011, the Company s cash and cash equivalents totaled $319 thousand and $1.9 million, respectively.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P19_S1	The liquidity of the Company varies, increasing to the extent cash flows from leases and proceeds of asset sales exceed expenses and decreasing as lease assets are acquired, as distributions are made to the Members and to the extent expenses exceed cash flows from leases and proceeds from asset sales.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P20_S0	The primary source of liquidity for the Company has been its cash flow from fixed-term leasing activities.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P20_S1	As the lease terms expire, the Company will re-lease or sell the equipment.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P20_S2	The future liquidity beyond the contractual minimum rentals will depend on the Company s success in remarketing or selling the equipment as it comes off-rental.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P21_S0	Throughout the Reinvestment Period (as defined in the Operating Agreement), the Company anticipates reinvesting a portion of lease payments from assets owned, and/or payments received on notes receivable, in new leasing or financing transactions.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P21_S1	Such reinvestment will occur only after the payment of all obligations, including debt service (both principal and interest), the payment of management fees to the Manager and providing for cash distributions to the Members.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P22_S0	If inflation in the general economy becomes significant, it may affect the Company in as much as the residual (resale) values and rates on re-leases of the Company s leased assets may increase as the costs of similar assets increase.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P22_S1	However, the Company s revenues from existing leases and notes would not increase as such rates are generally fixed for the terms of the leases and notes without adjustment for inflation.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P22_S2	In addition, if interest rates increase significantly under such circumstances, the rates that the Company can obtain on future lease or financing transactions will be expected to increase as the cost of capital is a significant factor in the pricing of leases and investments in notes receivable.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P22_S3	Leases and notes already in place, for the most part, would not be affected by changes in interest rates.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P23_S0	The Company currently believes it has available adequate reserves to meet its immediate cash requirements and those of the next twelve months, but in the event those reserves were found to be inadequate, the Company would likely be in a position to borrow against its current portfolio to meet such requirements.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P23_S1	The Managing Member envisions no such requirements for operating purposes.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P24_S0	The following table sets forth summary cash flow data (in thousands):
1394922_13_ITEM7_P25_S0	During 2012 and 2011, the Company s primary sources of liquidity were cash flows from its portfolio of operating and direct financing lease contracts, and its investments in notes receivable.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P25_S1	Moreover, the Company utilized borrowings totaling $3.5 million and $632 thousand for the respective twelve-month periods ended December 31, 2012 and 2011, and realized $393 thousand and $297 thousand of proceeds from sales of lease assets and/or the early termination of notes receivable.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P26_S0	During the same comparative years, cash was primarily used to acquire lease assets and to fund investments in notes receivable.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P26_S1	Total equipment purchased amounted to $2.6 million and $3.2 million during 2012 and 2011, respectively, while loans funded totaled $1.4 million during 2012 as compared to none during the prior year.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P27_S0	In addition, cash was used to pay distributions to both Other Members and the Managing Member, totaling a combined $2.9 million for each of the twelve-month periods ended December 31, 2012 and 2011, and to pay down $2.9 million and $1.6 million of debt.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P27_S1	During the prior year, cash was also used to purchase investment securities totaling $127 thousand and to pay down liabilities related to costs reimbursable to affiliates.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P28_S0	The Company participates with AFS and certain of its affiliates in a revolving credit facility (the Credit Facility ) comprised of a working capital facility to AFS, an acquisition facility (the Acquisition Facility ) and a warehouse facility (the Warehouse Facility ) to AFS, the Company and affiliates, and a venture facility available to an affiliate, with a syndicate of financial institutions as lenders.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P29_S0	The Credit Facility includes certain financial and non-financial covenants applicable to each borrower, including the Company.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P29_S1	Such covenants include covenants typically found in credit facilities of the size and nature of the Credit Facility, such as accuracy of representations, good standing, absence of liens and material litigation, etc.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P29_S2	The Company was in compliance with all covenants under the Credit Facility as of December 31, 2012.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P29_S3	The Company considers certain financial covenants to be material to its ongoing use of the Credit Facility and these covenants are described below.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P30_S0	Under the Credit Facility, the Company is required to maintain a specific tangible net worth, to comply with a leverage ratio and an interest coverage ratio, and to comply with other terms expressed in the Credit Facility, including limitation on the incurrence of additional debt and guaranties, defaults, and delinquencies.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P30_S1	The material financial covenants are summarized as follows:
1394922_13_ITEM7_P31_S0	Minimum Tangible Net Worth: $7.5 million Leverage Ratio (leverage to Tangible Net Worth): Not to exceed 1.25 to 1 Collateral Value:
1394922_13_ITEM7_P32_S0	EBITDA is defined under the Credit Facility as, for the relevant period of time (1) gross revenues (all payments from leases and notes receivable) for such period minus (2) expenses deducted in determining net income for such period plus (3) to the extent deducted in determining net income for such period (a) provision for income taxes and (b) interest expense, and (c) depreciation, amortization and other non-cash charges.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P32_S1	Extraordinary items and gains or losses on (and proceeds from) sales or dispositions of assets outside of the ordinary course of business are excluded in the calculation of EBITDA.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P33_S0	Tangible Net Worth is defined as, as of the date of determination, (i) the net worth of the Company, after deducting therefrom (without duplication of deductions) the net book amount of all assets of the Company, after deducting any reserves and other amounts for assets which would be treated as intangibles under accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( GAAP ), and after certain other adjustments permitted under the agreements.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P34_S0	The financial covenants referred to above are applicable to the Company only to the extent that the Company has borrowings outstanding under the Credit Facility.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P34_S1	As of December 31, 2012, the Company s Tangible Net Worth requirement under the Credit Facility was $7.5 million, the permitted maximum leverage ratio was 1.25 to 1, and the required minimum interest coverage ratio (EBITDA/interest expense) was 2 to 1.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P34_S2	The Company was in compliance with each of these financial covenants with a minimum Tangible Net Worth, leverage ratio and (EBITDA) interest coverage ratio, as calculated per the Credit Facility agreement of $11.5 million, 0.30 to 1, and 36.67 to 1, respectively, as of December 31, 2012.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P34_S3	As such, as of December 31, 2012, the Company was in compliance with all such material financial covenants.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P35_S0	For purposes of compliance with the Credit Facility covenants, the Company uses a financial calculation of EBITDA, as defined therein, which is a non-GAAP financial performance measure.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P35_S1	The EBITDA is utilized by the Company to calculate its debt covenant ratios.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P36_S0	The following is a reconciliation of net income to EBITDA, as defined in the loan agreement, for the twelve months ended December 31, 2012 (in thousands):
1394922_13_ITEM7_P37_S0	The terms of the Credit Facility include standard events of default by the Company which, if not cured within applicable grace periods, could give lenders remedies against the Company, including the acceleration of all outstanding borrowings and a demand for repayment in advance of their stated maturity.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P37_S1	If a breach of any material term of the Credit Facility should occur, the lenders may, at their option, increase borrowing rates, accelerate the obligations in advance of their stated maturities, terminate the facility, and exercise rights of collection available to them under the express terms of the facility, or by operation of law.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P37_S2	The lenders also retain the discretion to waive a violation of any covenant at the Company s request.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P38_S0	The Company is currently in compliance with its obligations under the Credit Facility.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P38_S1	In the event of a technical default (e.g., the failure to timely file a required report, or a one-time breach of a financial covenant), the Company believes it has ample time to request and be granted a waiver by the lenders, or, alternatively, cure the default under the existing provisions of its debt agreements, including, if necessary, arranging for additional capital from alternate sources to satisfy outstanding obligations.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P39_S0	The lending syndicate providing the Credit Facility has a blanket lien on all of the Company s assets as collateral for any and all borrowings under the Acquisition Facility, and on a pro-rata basis under the Warehouse Facility.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P40_S0	The Acquisition Facility is generally recourse solely to the Company, and is not cross-defaulted to any other obligations of affiliated companies under the Credit Facility, except as described in this paragraph.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P40_S1	The Credit Facility is cross-defaulted to a default in the payment of any debt (other than non-recourse debt) or any other agreement or condition beyond the period of grace (not exceeding 30 days), the effect of which would entitle the lender under such agreement to accelerate the obligations prior to their stated maturity in an individual or aggregate principal amount in excess of 15% of the Company s consolidated Tangible Net Worth.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P40_S2	Also, a bankruptcy of AFS will trigger a default for the Company under the Credit Facility.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P41_S0	As of December 31, 2012, the Company had non-recourse long-term debt totaling $3.4 million.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P41_S1	Such non-recourse notes payable do not contain any material financial covenants.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P41_S2	The notes are secured by a lien granted by the Company to the non-recourse lenders on (and only on) the discounted lease transactions.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P41_S3	The lenders have recourse only to the following collateral: the specific leased equipment; the related lease chattel paper; the lease receivables; and proceeds of the foregoing items.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P42_S0	For detailed information on the Company s debt obligations, see Notes 8 and 9 to the financial statements as set forth in Part II, Item 8, Financial Statements and Supplementary Data.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P43_S0	The Company commenced periodic distributions, based on cash flows from operations, beginning with the month of February 2008.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P43_S1	Additional distributions have been consistently made through December 31, 2012.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P43_S2	See Item 5, Market for Registrant s Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities, for additional information regarding the distributions.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P44_S0	At December 31, 2012, the Company had commitments to purchase lease assets totaling approximately $1.0 million and to fund investments in notes receivable totaling approximately $350 thousand (see Note 10, Commitments, as set forth in Part II, Item 8, Financial Statements and Supplementary Data).
1394922_13_ITEM7_P45_S0	Recent accounting standards updates as issued by the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) were evaluated and determined to be not applicable to the Company.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P46_S0	The policies discussed below are considered by management of the Company to be critical to an understanding of the Company s financial statements because their application requires significantly complex or subjective judgments, decisions, or assessments, with financial reporting results relying on estimation about the effect of matters that are inherently uncertain.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P46_S1	Specific risks for these critical accounting policies are described in the following paragraphs.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P46_S2	The Company also states these accounting policies in the notes to the financial statements and in relevant sections in this discussion and analysis.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P46_S3	For all of these policies, management cautions that future events rarely develop exactly as forecast, and the best estimates routinely require adjustment.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P47_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P47_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P47_S2	Such estimates primarily relate to the determination of residual values at the end of the lease term and expected future cash flows used for impairment analysis purposes and for determination of the allowance for doubtful accounts and reserve for credit losses on notes receivable.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P48_S0	Equipment on operating leases and related revenue recognition:
1394922_13_ITEM7_P49_S0	Equipment subject to operating leases is stated at cost.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P49_S1	Depreciation is recognized on a straight-line method over the terms of the related leases to the equipment s estimated residual values.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P49_S2	Maintenance costs associated with the Fund s portfolio of leased assets are expensed as incurred.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P49_S3	Major additions and betterments are capitalized.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P50_S0	Operating lease revenue is recognized on a straight-line basis over the term of the underlying leases.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P50_S1	The initial lease terms will vary as to the type of equipment subject to the leases, the needs of the lessees and the terms to be negotiated, but initial leases are generally on terms from 36 to 120 months.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P50_S2	The difference between rent received and rental revenue recognized is recorded as unearned operating lease income on the balance sheet.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P51_S0	Operating leases are generally placed in a non-accrual status (i.e., no revenue is recognized) when payments are more than 90 days past due.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P51_S1	Additionally, management considers the equipment underlying the lease contracts for impairment and periodically reviews the credit worthiness of all operating lessees with payments outstanding less than 90 days.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P51_S2	Based upon management s judgment, the related operating leases may be placed on non-accrual status.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P51_S3	Leases placed on non-accrual status are only returned to an accrual status when the account has been brought current and management believes recovery of the remaining unpaid lease payments is probable.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P51_S4	Until such time, revenues are recognized on a cash basis.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P52_S0	Direct financing leases and related revenue recognition:
1394922_13_ITEM7_P53_S0	Income from direct financing lease transactions is reported using the financing method of accounting, in which the Company s investment in the leased property is reported as a receivable from the lessee to be recovered through future rentals.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P53_S1	The interest income portion of each rental payment is calculated so as to generate a constant rate of return on the net receivable outstanding.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P54_S0	Allowances for losses on direct financing leases are typically established based on historical charge-off and collection experience and the collectability of specifically identified lessees and billed and unbilled receivables.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P54_S1	Direct financing leases are charged off to the allowance as they are deemed uncollectible.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P55_S0	Direct financing leases are generally placed in a non-accrual status (i.e., no revenue is recognized) and deemed impaired when payments are more than 90 days past due.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P55_S1	Additionally, management periodically reviews the creditworthiness of all direct finance lessees with payments outstanding less than 90 days.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P55_S2	Based upon management s judgment, the related direct financing leases may be placed on non-accrual status.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P55_S3	Leases placed on non-accrual status are only returned to an accrual status when the account has been brought current and management believes recovery of the remaining unpaid lease payments is probable.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P55_S4	Until such time, all payments received are applied only against outstanding principal balances.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P56_S0	Notes receivable, unearned interest income and related revenue recognition:
1394922_13_ITEM7_P57_S0	The Company records all future payments of principal and interest on notes as notes receivable, which are then offset by the amount of any related unearned interest income.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P57_S1	For financial statement purposes, the Company reports only the net amount of principal due on the balance sheet.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P57_S2	The unearned interest is recognized over the term of the note and the income portion of each note payment is calculated so as to generate a constant rate of return on the net balance outstanding.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P57_S3	Any fees or costs related to notes receivable are recorded as part of the net investment in notes receivable and amortized over the term of the loan.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P58_S0	Allowances for losses on notes receivable are typically established based on historical charge-off and collection experience and the collectability of specifically identified borrowers and billed and unbilled receivables.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P58_S1	Notes are considered impaired when, based on current information and events, it is probable that the Company will be unable to collect the scheduled payments of principal and/or interest when due according to the contractual terms of the note agreement.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P58_S2	Factors considered by management in determining impairment include payment status, collateral value, and the probability of collecting scheduled principal and interest when due.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P58_S3	If it is determined that a loan is impaired with regard to scheduled payments, the Company will perform an analysis of the note to determine if an impairment valuation reserve is necessary.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P58_S4	This analysis considers the estimated cash flows from the note, or the collateral value of the property underlying the note when note repayment is collateral dependent.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P58_S5	Any required valuation reserve is charged to earnings when determined; and notes are charged off to the allowance as they are deemed uncollectible.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P59_S0	Notes receivable are generally placed in a non-accrual status (i.e., no revenue is recognized) when payments are more than 90 days past due.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P59_S1	Additionally, management periodically reviews the creditworthiness of companies with note payments outstanding less than 90 days.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P59_S2	Based upon management s judgment, notes may be placed in a non-accrual status.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P59_S3	Notes placed on non-accrual status are only returned to an accrual status when the account has been brought current and management believes recovery of the remaining unpaid receivable is probable.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P59_S4	Until such time, all payments received are applied only against outstanding principal balances.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P60_S0	The Company capitalizes initial direct costs ( IDC ) associated with the origination and funding of lease assets and investments in notes receivable.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P60_S1	IDC includes both internal costs (e.g., the costs of employees activities in connection with successful lease and loan originations) and external broker fees incurred with such originations.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P60_S2	The costs are amortized on a lease by lease (or note by note) basis based on actual contract term using a straight-line method for operating leases and the effective interest rate method for direct financing leases and notes receivable.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P60_S3	Upon disposal of the underlying lease or loan assets, both the initial direct costs and the associated accumulated amortization are relieved.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P60_S4	Costs related to leases or notes receivable that are not consummated are not eligible for capitalization as initial direct costs and are expensed as acquisition expense.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P61_S0	Recorded values of the Company s leased asset portfolio are periodically reviewed for impairment.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P61_S1	An impairment loss is measured and recognized only if the estimated undiscounted future cash flows of the asset are less than their net book value.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P61_S2	The estimated undiscounted future cash flows are the sum of the estimated residual value of the asset at the end of the asset s expected holding period and estimates of undiscounted future rents.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P61_S3	The residual value assumes, among other things, that the asset is utilized normally in an open, unrestricted and stable market.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P62_S0	significant number of the assets, if held in quantity, simultaneously or to dispose of the asset quickly.
1394922_13_ITEM7_P63_S0	Impairment is measured as the difference between the fair value (as determined by a valuation method using discounted estimated future cash flows, third party appraisals or comparable sales of similar assets as applicable based on asset type) of the assets and its carrying value on the measurement date.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P0_S0	See the Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm, Financial Statements and Notes to Financial Statements attached hereto at pages 15 through 38 .
1394922_13_ITEM8_P1_S0	We have audited the accompanying balance sheets of ATEL 12, LLC (the Company ) as of December 31, 2012 and 2011, and the related statements of income, changes in members capital, and cash flows for the years then ended.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P1_S1	These financial statements are the responsibility of the Management of the Company s Managing Member.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P1_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P2_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1394922_13_ITEM8_P2_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P2_S2	We were not engaged to perform an audit of the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P2_S3	Our audits included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P2_S4	Accordingly, we express no such opinion.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P3_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P3_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P3_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P4_S0	In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of ATEL 12, LLC as of December 31, 2012 and 2011, and the results of its operations and its cash flows for the years then ended, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P5_S0	Organization and Limited Liability Company matters:
1394922_13_ITEM8_P6_S0	ATEL 12, LLC (the Company or the Fund ) was formed under the laws of the state of California on January 25, 2007 for the purpose of equipment financing and acquiring equipment to engage in equipment leasing and sales activities, as well as in real estate, growth capital investment activities and green technologies (the principal operations ).
1394922_13_ITEM8_P6_S1	The Managing Member of the Company is ATEL Associates 12, LLC (the Managing Member ), a Nevada limited liability company.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P6_S2	The Fund may continue until December 31, 2030.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P7_S0	As a limited liability company, the liability of any individual member for the obligations of the Fund is limited to the extent of capital contributions to the Fund by the individual member.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P8_S0	The Company conducted a public offering of 20,000,000 Limited Liability Company Units ( Units ), at a price of $10 per Unit.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P8_S1	On January 24, 2008, subscriptions for the minimum number of Units (120,000, representing $1.2 million), excluding subscriptions from Pennsylvania investors, had been received and the Fund requested subscription proceeds to be released from escrow.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P8_S2	On that date, the Company commenced initial operations and continued in its development stage activities until transitioning to an operating enterprise during the second quarter of 2008.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P9_S0	Pennsylvania subscriptions were subject to a separate escrow to be released to the Fund only when the Fund had received aggregate subscriptions for all investors equal to at least $7.5 million.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P9_S1	Total contributions to the Fund exceeded $7.5 million on July 15, 2008.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P9_S2	The offering was terminated on September 25, 2009.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P10_S0	As of December 31, 2012, cumulative contributions, net of rescissions and repurchases, totaling $29.9 million (inclusive of the $500 initial member s capital investment) have been received and 2,993,482 Units were issued and outstanding.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P11_S0	The Fund, or Managing Member and/or affiliates on behalf of the Fund, has incurred costs in connection with the organization, registration and issuance of the Units.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P11_S1	The amount of such costs to be borne by the Fund is limited by certain provisions of the ATEL 12, LLC Limited Liability Company Operating Agreement dated April 3, 2007 (the Operating Agreement ).
1394922_13_ITEM8_P12_S0	The Company s principal objectives are to invest in a diversified portfolio of investments that (i) preserves, protects and returns the Company s invested capital; (ii) generates regular cash distributions to Unitholders, any balance remaining after required minimum distributions to be used to purchase additional investments during the reinvestment period ( Reinvestment Period ) (defined as six full years following the year the offering was terminated) which ends on December 31, 2015 and (iii) provides additional cash distributions following the Reinvestment Period and until all investment portfolio assets have been sold or otherwise disposed.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P12_S1	The Company is governed by its Operating Agreement, as amended.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P13_S0	The accompanying balance sheets as of December 31, 2012 and 2011, and the related statements of income, changes in members capital, and cash flows for the years then ended, have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( GAAP ) and the rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P13_S1	Certain prior year amounts have been reclassified to conform to the current year presentation.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P13_S2	These reclassifications had no significant effect on the reported financial position or results of operations.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P14_S0	Footnote and tabular amounts are presented in thousands, except as to Units and per Unit data.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P15_S0	In preparing the accompanying financial statements, the Company has reviewed, as determined necessary by the Managing Member, events that have occurred after December 31, 2012, up until the issuance of the financial statements.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P15_S1	No events were noted which would require disclosure in the footnotes to the financial statements.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P16_S0	Cash and cash equivalents include cash in banks and cash equivalent investments such as U.S. Treasury instruments with original and/or purchased maturities of ninety days or less.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P17_S0	The preparation of the financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P17_S1	Actual results could differ from the estimates.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P17_S2	Such estimates primarily relate to the determination of residual values at the end of the lease term and expected future cash flows used for impairment analysis purposes and determination of the allowances for doubtful accounts and reserve for credit losses on notes receivable.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P18_S0	Accounts receivable represent the amounts billed under operating and direct financing lease contracts, and notes receivable which are currently due to the Company.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P18_S1	Allowances for doubtful accounts are typically established based on historical charge off and collection experience and the collectability of specifically identified lessees and borrowers, and invoiced amounts.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P18_S2	Accounts receivable deemed uncollectible are generally charged off against the allowance on a specific identification basis.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P19_S0	Recoveries of amounts that were previously written-off are recorded as other income in the period received.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P20_S0	Financial instruments that potentially subject the Company to concentrations of credit risk include cash and cash equivalents, operating and direct financing lease receivables, notes receivable and accounts receivable.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P20_S1	The Company places the majority of its cash deposits in noninterest-bearing accounts with financial institutions that have no less than $10 billion in assets.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P20_S2	Such deposits are insured up to $250 thousand.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P20_S3	The remainder of the Funds cash is temporarily invested in U.S. Treasury denominated instruments.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P20_S4	The concentration of such deposits and temporary cash investments is not deemed to create a significant risk to the Company.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P21_S0	Accounts and notes receivable represent amounts due from lessees or borrowers in various industries, related to equipment on operating and direct financing leases or notes receivable.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P22_S0	Equipment on operating leases and related revenue recognition:
1394922_13_ITEM8_P23_S0	Equipment subject to operating leases is stated at cost.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P23_S1	Depreciation is recognized on a straight-line method over the terms of the related leases to the equipment s estimated residual values.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P23_S2	Maintenance costs associated with the Fund s portfolio of leased assets are expensed as incurred.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P23_S3	Major additions and betterments are capitalized.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P24_S0	Operating lease revenue is recognized on a straight-line basis over the term of the underlying leases.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P24_S1	The initial lease terms will vary as to the type of equipment subject to the leases, the needs of the lessees and the terms to be negotiated, but initial leases are generally on terms from 36 to 120 months.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P24_S2	The difference between rent received and rental revenue recognized is recorded as unearned operating lease income on the balance sheet.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P25_S0	Operating leases are generally placed in a non-accrual status (i.e., no revenue is recognized) when payments are more than 90 days past due.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P25_S1	Additionally, management considers the equipment underlying the lease contracts for impairment and periodically reviews the credit worthiness of all operating lessees with payments outstanding less than 90 days.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P25_S2	Based upon management s judgment, the related operating leases may be placed on non-accrual status.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P25_S3	Leases placed on non-accrual status are only returned to an accrual status when the account has been brought current and management believes recovery of the remaining unpaid lease payments is probable.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P25_S4	Until such time, revenues are recognized on a cash basis.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P26_S0	Direct financing leases and related revenue recognition:
1394922_13_ITEM8_P27_S0	Income from direct financing lease transactions is reported using the financing method of accounting, in which the Company s investment in the leased property is reported as a receivable from the lessee to be recovered through future rentals.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P27_S1	The interest income portion of each rental payment is calculated so as to generate a constant rate of return on the net receivable outstanding.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P28_S0	Allowances for losses on direct financing leases are typically established based on historical charge-off and collection experience and the collectability of specifically identified lessees and billed and unbilled receivables.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P28_S1	Direct financing leases are charged off to the allowance as they are deemed uncollectible.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P29_S0	Direct financing leases are generally placed in a non-accrual status (i.e., no revenue is recognized) and deemed impaired when payments are more than 90 days past due.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P29_S1	Additionally, management periodically reviews the creditworthiness of all direct finance lessees with payments outstanding less than 90 days.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P29_S2	Based upon management s judgment, the related direct financing leases may be placed on non-accrual status.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P29_S3	Leases placed on non-accrual status are only returned to an accrual status when the account has been brought current and management believes recovery of the remaining unpaid lease payments is probable.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P29_S4	Until such time, all payments received are applied only against outstanding principal balances.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P30_S0	Notes receivable, unearned interest income and related revenue recognition:
1394922_13_ITEM8_P31_S0	The Company records all future payments of principal and interest on notes as notes receivable, which are then offset by the amount of any related unearned interest income.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P31_S1	For financial statement purposes, the Company reports only the net amount of principal due on the balance sheet.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P31_S2	The unearned interest is recognized over the term of the note and the income portion of each note payment is calculated so as to generate a constant rate of return on the net balance outstanding.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P31_S3	Any fees or costs related to notes receivable are recorded as part of the net investment in notes receivable and amortized over the term of the loan.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P32_S0	Allowances for losses on notes receivable are typically established based on historical charge off and collection experience and the collectability of specifically identified borrowers and billed and unbilled receivables.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P32_S1	Notes are considered impaired when, based on current information and events, it is probable that the Company will be unable to collect the scheduled payments of principal and/or interest when due according to the contractual terms of the note agreement.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P32_S2	Factors considered by management in determining impairment include payment status, collateral value, and the probability of collecting scheduled principal and interest when due.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P32_S3	If it is determined that a loan is impaired with regard to scheduled payments, the Company will perform an analysis of the note to determine if an impairment valuation reserve is necessary.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P32_S4	This analysis considers the estimated cash flows from the note, or the collateral value of the property underlying the note when note repayment is collateral dependent.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P32_S5	Any required valuation reserve is charged to earnings when determined; and notes are charged off to the allowance as they are deemed uncollectible.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P33_S0	Notes receivable are generally placed in a non-accrual status (i.e., no revenue is recognized) when payments are more than 90 days past due.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P33_S1	Additionally, management periodically reviews the creditworthiness of companies with note payments outstanding less than 90 days.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P33_S2	Based upon management s judgment, notes may be placed in a non-accrual status.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P33_S3	Notes placed on non-accrual status are only returned to an accrual status when the account has been brought current and management believes recovery of the remaining unpaid receivable is probable.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P33_S4	Until such time, all payments received are applied only against outstanding principal balances.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P34_S0	The Company capitalizes initial direct costs ( IDC ) associated with the origination and funding of lease assets and investments in notes receivable.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P34_S1	IDC includes both internal costs (e.g., the costs of employees activities in connection with successful lease and loan originations) and external broker fees incurred with such originations.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P34_S2	The costs are amortized on a lease by lease (or note by note) basis based on actual lease term using a straight-line method for operating leases and the effective interest rate method for direct financing leases and notes receivable.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P34_S3	Upon disposal of the underlying lease or loan assets, both the initial direct costs and the associated accumulated amortization are relieved.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P34_S4	Costs related to leases or notes receivable that are not consummated are not eligible for capitalization as initial direct costs and are expensed as acquisition expense.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P35_S0	Acquisition expense represents costs which include, but are not limited to, legal fees and expenses, travel and communication expenses, cost of appraisals, accounting fees and expenses and miscellaneous expenses related to the selection and acquisition of equipment which are reimbursable to the Managing Member under the terms of the Operating Agreement.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P35_S1	As the costs are not eligible for capitalization as initial direct costs, such amounts are expensed as incurred.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P36_S0	Recorded values of the Company s leased asset portfolio are periodically reviewed for impairment.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P36_S1	An impairment loss is measured and recognized only if the estimated undiscounted future cash flows of the asset are less than their net book value.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P36_S2	The estimated undiscounted future cash flows are the sum of the estimated residual value of the asset at the end of the asset s expected holding period and estimates of undiscounted future rents.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P36_S3	The residual value assumes, among other things, that the asset is utilized normally in an open, unrestricted and stable market.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P36_S4	Short-term fluctuations in the market place are disregarded and it is assumed that there is no necessity either to dispose of a significant number of the assets, if held in quantity, simultaneously or to dispose of the asset quickly.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P37_S0	Impairment is measured as the difference between the fair value (as determined by a valuation method using discounted estimated future cash flows, third party appraisals or comparable sales of similar assets as applicable based on asset type) of the asset and its carrying value on the measurement date.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P38_S0	The Company is organized into one operating segment for the purpose of making operating decisions or assessing performance.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P38_S1	Accordingly, the Company operates in one reportable operating segment in the United States.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P39_S0	The Company s principal decision makers are the Managing Member s Chief Executive Officer and its Chief Financial Officer and Chief Operating Officer.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P39_S1	The Company believes that its equipment leasing business operates as one reportable segment because: a) the Company measures profit and loss at the equipment portfolio level as a whole; b) the principal decision makers do not review information based on any operating segment other than the equipment leasing transaction portfolio; c) the Company does not maintain discrete financial information on any specific segment other than its equipment financing operations; d) the Company has not chosen to organize its business around different products and services other than equipment lease financing; and e) the Company has not chosen to organize its business around geographic areas.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P40_S0	The primary geographic regions in which the Company sought leasing opportunities were North America and Europe.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P40_S1	For the years ended December 31, 2012 and 2011, and as of December 31, 2012 and 2011, 100% of the Company s operating revenues and long-lived assets are from customers domiciled in North America.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P41_S0	Purchased securities Purchased securities are generally not registered for public sale and are carried at cost.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P41_S1	Such securities are adjusted to fair value if the fair value is less than the carrying value and such impairment is deemed by the Managing Member to be other than temporary.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P42_S0	Factors considered by the Managing Member in determining fair value include, but are not limited to, available financial information, the issuer s ability to meet its current obligations and indications of the issuer s subsequent ability to raise capital.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P42_S1	Based upon the Company s review of its portfolio, no fair value adjustment was deemed necessary during 2012.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P42_S2	During the second quarter of 2011, the Company deemed an investment security to be impaired and recorded a fair value adjustment of $5 thousand which reduced the cost basis of the investment.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P42_S3	No subsequent fair value adjustment was recorded through December 31, 2011.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P43_S0	Warrants Warrants owned by the Company are not registered for public sale, but are considered derivatives and are carried at an estimated fair value on the balance sheet at the end of the period, as determined by the Managing Member.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P44_S0	There were no warrants exercised during 2012.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P44_S1	During the second quarter of 2011, the Company recognized a gain of $17 thousand relative to the net exercise of warrants associated with shares of a venture company.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P44_S2	During the third quarter of 2011, the Company disposed of the aforementioned security and recognized a nominal loss.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P45_S0	The Company records prepayments on operating leases as a liability under the caption of unearned operating lease income.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P45_S1	The liability is recorded when prepayments are received and recognized as operating lease revenue over the period to which the prepayments relate using a straight-line method.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P46_S0	The Company is treated as a partnership for federal income tax purposes.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P46_S1	Pursuant to the provisions of Section 701 of the Internal Revenue Code, a partnership is not subject to federal income taxes.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P46_S2	Accordingly, the Company has provided current franchise income taxes for only those states which levy income taxes on partnerships.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P46_S3	For the years ended December 31, 2012 and 2011, the related provision for state income taxes was approximately $16 thousand and $12 thousand, respectively.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P46_S4	The Company does not have any entity level uncertain tax positions.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P47_S0	The Company files income tax returns in the U.S. federal jurisdiction and various state jurisdictions and is generally subject to examination by U.S. federal (or state and local) income tax authorities for three years from the filing of a tax return.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P48_S0	The tax bases of the Company s net assets and liabilities vary from the amounts presented in these financial statements at December 31, 2012 and 2011 as follows (in thousands):
1394922_13_ITEM8_P49_S0	The primary differences between the tax bases of net assets and the amounts recorded in the financial statements are the result of differences in accounting for impairment losses, syndication costs and differences between the depreciation methods used in the financial statements and the Company s tax returns.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P50_S0	The following reconciles the net income reported in these financial statements to the loss reported on the Company s federal tax return (unaudited) for the years ended December 31, 2012 and 2011 (in thousands):
1394922_13_ITEM8_P51_S0	Net income and distributions per Unit are based upon the weighted average number of Other Members Units outstanding during the year.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P52_S0	Recent accounting standards updates as issued by the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) were evaluated and determined to be not applicable to the Company.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P53_S0	Concentration of credit risk and major customers:
1394922_13_ITEM8_P54_S0	The Company leases equipment to lessees and provides debt financing to borrowers in diversified industries.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P54_S1	Leases and notes receivable are subject to the Managing Member s credit committee review.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P54_S2	The leases and notes receivable provide for the return of the equipment to the Company upon default.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P55_S0	As of December 31, 2012 and 2011, there were concentrations (greater than 10% as a percentage of total equipment cost) of equipment leased to lessees and/or financial borrowers in certain industries as follows:
1394922_13_ITEM8_P56_S0	During 2012 and 2011, certain lessees generated significant portions (defined as 10% or more) of the Company s total leasing and lending revenues as follows:
1394922_13_ITEM8_P57_S0	The Company has various notes receivable from borrowers who have financed the purchase of equipment through the Company.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P57_S1	At December 31, 2012, the terms of the notes receivable are 17 to 42 months and bear interest at rates ranging from 11.26% to 18.00%.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P57_S2	The notes are generally secured by the equipment financed.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P57_S3	The notes mature from 2013 through 2015.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P58_S0	The Company had no notes in non-accrual status at December 31, 2012.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P58_S1	By comparison, the Company had two notes in non-accrual status at December 31, 2011.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P59_S0	The notes in non-accrual status at December 31, 2011 were originally placed in non-accrual status in 2010, at which time their terms were modified to defer the repayment of principal until April 2012 while maintaining interest-only payments at their original rates of 11.58% and 11.78%, respectively.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P59_S1	From April 1, 2012 well into the third quarter, the interest only payment arrangement was continued pending a final resolution of the terms of repayment.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P59_S2	Just prior to the end of the third quarter, past due amounts were received bringing both notes current at September 30, 2012.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P60_S0	Accordingly, both notes were returned to accrual status effective October 1, 2012.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P60_S1	As of December 31, 2012, the aforementioned notes reflect principal balances outstanding of $10 thousand and $12 thousand, respectively.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P60_S2	Through December 31, 2012, the Company had previously accumulated $22 thousand of fair value adjustments to reduce the fair value of the impaired notes.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P61_S0	During the second quarter of 2012, an additional note was deemed to be impaired and placed in non-accrual status.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P61_S1	As such, the Company recorded a fair value adjustment of $27 thousand which reduced the cost basis of the impaired note.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P61_S2	No additional adjustment was recorded through December 31, 2012.

1394922_13_ITEM8_P61_S4	The note was returned to accrual status effective October 1, 2012.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P61_S5	As of the same date, the note reflects a principal balance outstanding of $85 thousand.

1394922_13_ITEM8_P64_S0	The Company s allowance for credit losses are as follows (in thousands):
1394922_13_ITEM8_P65_S0	Accounts receivable represent the amounts billed under operating and direct financing lease contracts, and notes receivable which are currently due to the Company.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P66_S0	Allowances for doubtful accounts are typically established based upon their aging and historical charge off and collection experience and the creditworthiness of specifically identified lessees and borrowers, and invoiced amounts.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P66_S1	Accounts receivable deemed uncollectible are generally charged off against the allowance on a specific identification basis.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P67_S0	Recoveries of amounts that were previously written-off are recorded as other income in the period received.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P68_S0	Accounts receivable are generally placed in a non-accrual status (i.e., no revenue is recognized) when payments are more than 90 days past due.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P68_S1	Additionally, management periodically reviews the creditworthiness of companies with lease or note payments outstanding less than 90 days.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P68_S2	Based upon management s judgment, such leases or notes may be placed in non-accrual status.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P68_S3	Leases or notes placed on non-accrual status are only returned to an accrual status when the account has been brought current and management believes recovery of the remaining unpaid receivable is probable.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P68_S4	Until such time, revenues on operating leases are recognized on a cash basis.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P68_S5	All payments received on amounts billed under direct financing leases contracts and notes receivable are applied only against outstanding principal balances.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P69_S0	In addition to the allowance established for delinquent accounts receivable, the total allowance related solely to financing receivables also includes anticipated impairment charges on notes receivable and direct financing leases.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P70_S0	Notes are considered impaired when, based on current information and events, it is probable that the Company will be unable to collect the scheduled payments of principal and/or interest when due according to the contractual terms of the note agreement.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P70_S1	Factors considered by management in determining impairment include payment status, collateral value, and the probability of collecting scheduled principal and interest when due.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P70_S2	If it is determined that a loan is impaired with regard to scheduled payments, the Company will perform an analysis of the note to determine if an impairment valuation reserve is necessary.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P70_S3	This analysis considers the estimated cash flows from the note, or the collateral value of the property underlying the note when note repayment is collateral dependent.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P70_S4	Any required valuation reserve is charged to earnings when determined; and notes are charged off to the allowance as they are deemed uncollectible.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P71_S0	The asset underlying a direct financing lease contract is considered impaired if the estimated undiscounted future cash flows of the asset are less than its net book value.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P71_S1	The estimated undiscounted future cash flows are the sum of the estimated residual value of the asset at the end of the asset s expected holding period and estimates of undiscounted future rents.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P71_S2	The residual value assumes, among other things, that the asset is utilized normally in an open, unrestricted and stable market.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P71_S3	Short-term fluctuations in the market place are disregarded and it is assumed that there is no necessity either to dispose of a significant number of the assets, if held in quantity, simultaneously or to dispose of the asset quickly.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P72_S0	Impairment is measured as the difference between the fair value (as determined by a valuation method using discounted estimated future cash flows, third party appraisals or comparable sales of similar assets as applicable based on asset type) of the asset and its carrying value on the measurement date.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P73_S0	The Company s allowance for credit losses (related solely to financing receivables) and its recorded investment in financing receivables as of December 31, 2012 and 2011 were as follows (in thousands):
1394922_13_ITEM8_P74_S0	Includes $6 of unamortized initial direct costs.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P75_S0	Includes $6 of unamortized initial direct costs.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P76_S0	The Company evaluates the credit quality of its financing receivables on a scale equivalent to the following quality indicators related to corporate risk profiles:
1394922_13_ITEM8_P77_S0	Pass Any account whose lessee/debtor, co-lessee/debtor or any guarantor has a credit rating on publicly traded or privately placed debt issues as rated by Moody s or S P for either Senior Unsecured debt, Long Term Issuer rating or Issuer rating that are in the tiers of ratings generally recognized by the investment community as constituting an Investment Grade credit rating; or, has been determined by the Manager to be an Investment Grade Equivalent or High Quality Corporate Credit per its Credit Policy or has a Not Rated internal rating by the Manager and the account is not considered by the Chief Credit Officer of the manager to fall into one of the three risk profiles below.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P78_S0	Any traditional corporate type account with potential weaknesses (e.g., large net losses or major industry downturns) or, any growth capital account that has less than three months of cash as of the end of the calendar quarter to fund their continuing operations.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P78_S1	These accounts deserve management s close attention.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P78_S2	If left uncorrected, those potential weaknesses may result in deterioration of the Fund s receivable at some future date.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P79_S0	Substandard Any account that is inadequately protected by the current worth and paying capacity of the borrower or of the collateral pledged, if any.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P80_S0	Accounts that are so classified have a well-defined weakness or weaknesses that jeopardize the liquidation of the debt.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P80_S1	They are characterized by the distinct possibility that the Fund will sustain some loss as the likelihood of fully collecting all receivables may be questionable if the deficiencies are not corrected.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P80_S2	Such accounts are on the Manager s Credit Watch List.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P81_S0	Doubtful Any account where the weaknesses make collection or liquidation in full, on the basis of currently existing facts, conditions, and values, highly questionable and improbable.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P81_S1	Accordingly, an account that is so classified is on the Manager s Credit Watch List, and has been declared in default and the Manager has repossessed, or is attempting to repossess, the equipment it financed.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P82_S0	This category includes impaired notes and leases as applicable.

1394922_13_ITEM8_P84_S0	As of December 31, 2012 and 2011, the Company s impaired loans were as follows (in thousands):

1394922_13_ITEM8_P100_S0	The terms of the Operating Agreement provide that the Managing Member and/or affiliates are entitled to receive certain fees for equipment management and resale and for management of the Company.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P101_S0	The Operating Agreement allows for the reimbursement of costs incurred by Managing Member and/or affiliates for providing administrative services to the Company.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P101_S1	Administrative services provided include Company accounting, investor relations, legal counsel and lease and equipment documentation.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P101_S2	The Managing Member is not reimbursed for services whereby it is entitled to receive a separate fee as compensation for such services, such as management of investments.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P102_S0	The Company would be liable for certain future costs to be incurred by the Managing Member to manage the administrative services provided to the Company.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P103_S0	Each of ATEL Financial Services, LLC ( AFS ) and ATEL Leasing Corporation ( ALC ) is a wholly-owned subsidiary of ATEL Capital Group and performs services for the Company on behalf of the Managing Member.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P103_S1	Acquisition services, equipment management, lease administration and asset disposition services are performed by ALC; investor relations, communications and general administrative services are performed by AFS.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P104_S0	Cost reimbursements to the Managing Member or its affiliates are based on its costs incurred in performing administrative services for the Company.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P104_S1	These costs are allocated to each managed entity based on certain criteria such as managed assets, number of investors or contributed capital based upon the type of cost incurred.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P104_S2	The Managing Member believes that the costs reimbursed are the lower of (i) actual costs incurred on behalf of the Company or (ii) the amount the Company would be required to pay independent parties for comparable administrative services in the same geographic location.

1394922_13_ITEM8_P106_S0	At December 31, 2012, non-recourse debt consists of notes payable to financial institutions.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P106_S1	The notes are due in monthly installments.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P106_S2	Interest on the notes is at fixed rates ranging from 1.78% to 4.40% per annum.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P106_S3	The notes are secured by assignments of lease payments and pledges of assets.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P106_S4	At December 31, 2012, gross lease rentals totaled approximately $3.5 million over the remaining lease terms; and the carrying value of the pledged assets is approximately $5.5 million.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P106_S5	The notes mature at various dates from 2014 through 2015.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P107_S0	The non-recourse debt does not contain any material financial covenants.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P107_S1	The debt is secured by a specific lien granted by the Company to the non-recourse lenders on (and only on) the discounted lease transactions.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P107_S2	The lenders have recourse only to the following collateral: the leased equipment; the related lease chattel paper; the lease receivables; and proceeds of the foregoing items.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P107_S3	The non-recourse obligation is payable solely out of the respective specific security and the Company does not guarantee (nor is the Company otherwise contractually responsible for) the payment of the non-recourse debt as a general obligation or liability of the Company.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P107_S4	Although the Company does not have any direct or general liability in connection with the non-recourse debt apart from the security granted, the Company is directly and generally liable and responsible for certain representations, warranties, and covenants made to the lenders, such as warranties as to genuineness of the transaction parties' signatures, as to the genuineness of the respective lease chattel paper or the transaction as a whole, or as to the Company's good title to or perfected interest in the secured collateral, as well as similar representations, warranties and covenants typically provided by non-recourse borrowers and customary in the equipment finance industry, and are viewed by such industry as being consistent with non-recourse discount financing obligations.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P107_S5	Accordingly, as there are no financial covenants or ratios imposed on the Company in connection with the non-recourse debt, the Company has determined that there are no material covenants with respect to the non-recourse debt that warrant footnote disclosure.

1394922_13_ITEM8_P109_S0	The Company participates with AFS and certain of its affiliates in a revolving credit facility (the Credit Facility ) comprised of a working capital facility to AFS, an acquisition facility (the Acquisition Facility ) and a warehouse facility (the Warehouse Facility ) to AFS, the Company and affiliates, and a venture facility available to an affiliate, with a syndicate of financial institutions as lenders, and which Credit Facility includes certain financial covenants.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P109_S1	The Credit Facility is for an amount up to $60 million and expires in June 2014.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P109_S2	The lending syndicate providing the Credit Facility has a blanket lien on all of the Company s assets as collateral for any and all borrowings under the Acquisition Facility, and on a pro-rata basis under the Warehouse Facility.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P110_S0	As of December 31, 2012 and 2011, borrowings under the facility were as follows (in thousands):
1394922_13_ITEM8_P111_S0	The Company and its affiliates pay an annual commitment fee to have access to this line of credit.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P111_S1	As of December 31, 2012, the aggregate amount of the Credit Facility is potentially available to the Company, subject to certain sub-facility and borrowing-base limitations.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P112_S0	the affiliates who are borrowers under the Credit Facility, the amount remaining available to all borrowers to draw under the Credit Facility is reduced.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P112_S1	As the Warehousing Facility is a short term bridge facility, any amounts borrowed under the Warehousing Facility, and then repaid by the affiliated borrowers (including the Company) upon allocation of an acquisition to a specific purchaser, become available under the Warehouse Facility for further short term borrowing.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P113_S0	As of December 31, 2012, the Company s Tangible Net Worth requirement under the Credit Facility was $7.5 million, the permitted maximum leverage ratio was not to exceed 1.25 to 1, and the required minimum interest coverage ratio was not to be less than 2 to 1.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P113_S1	The Company was in compliance with these financial covenants under the Credit Facility with a minimum Tangible Net Worth, leverage ratio and interest coverage ratio, as calculated per the Credit Facility agreement of $11.5 million, 0.30 to 1, and 36.67 to 1, respectively, as of December 31, 2012.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P113_S2	As such, as of December 31, 2012, the Company was in compliance with all material financial covenants, and with all other material conditions of the Credit Facility.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P113_S3	The Company does not anticipate any covenant violations nor does it anticipate that any of these covenants will restrict its operations or its ability to procure additional financing.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P114_S0	The interest rate on the Credit Facility is based on either the LIBOR/Eurocurrency rate of 1-, 2-, 3- or 6-month maturity plus a lender designated spread, or the bank s Prime rate, which re-prices daily.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P115_S0	Principal amounts of loans made under the Credit Facility that are prepaid may be re-borrowed on the terms and subject to the conditions set forth under the Credit Facility.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P115_S1	There were no borrowings outstanding as of December 31, 2012 and 2011.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P115_S2	During the first six months of 2012 and 2011, the Company borrowed and repaid $1.5 million and $632 thousand, respectively.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P115_S3	The weighted average rate on such borrowings was 3.30% and 3.29% during 2012 and 2011, respectively.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P116_S0	To hold the assets under the Warehousing Facility prior to allocation to specific investor programs, a Warehousing Trust has been entered into by the Company, AFS, ALC, and certain of the affiliated partnerships and limited liability companies.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P116_S1	The Warehousing Trust is used by the Warehouse Facility borrowers to acquire and hold, on a short-term basis, certain lease transactions that meet the investment objectives of each of such entities.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P116_S2	Each of the leasing programs sponsored by AFS and ALC is a pro rata participant in the Warehousing Trust, as described below.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P116_S3	When a program no longer has a need for short term financing provided by the Warehousing Facility, it is removed from participation, and as new leasing investment entities are formed by AFS and ALC and commence their acquisition stages, these new entities are added.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P117_S0	At the close of business on December 31, 2012, the investment program was renewed through June 2014 for the Company, ATEL 14, LLC, and ATEL 15, LLC.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P118_S0	Pursuant to the Warehousing Trust, the benefit of the lease transaction assets, and the corresponding liabilities under the Warehouse Facility, inure to each of such entities based upon each entity s pro-rata share in the Warehousing Trust estate.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P118_S1	The pro-rata share is calculated as a ratio of the net worth of each entity over the aggregate net worth of all entities benefiting from the Warehousing Trust estate, excepting that the trustees, AFS and ALC, are both jointly and severally liable for the pro rata portion of the obligations of each of the affiliated partnerships and limited liability companies participating under the Warehouse Facility.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P118_S2	Transactions are financed through this Warehouse Facility only until the transactions are allocated to a specific program for purchase or are otherwise disposed by AFS and ALC.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P118_S3	When a determination is made to allocate the transaction to a specific program for purchase by the program, the purchaser repays the debt associated with the asset, either with cash or by means of proceeds of a draw under the Acquisition Facility, and the asset is removed from the Warehouse Facility collateral, and ownership of the asset and any debt obligation associated with the asset are assumed solely by the purchasing entity.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P119_S0	As of December 31, 2012, there were no borrowings under the Warehouse Facility.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P119_S1	As of December 31, 2011, borrowings of $5.6 million were outstanding under such facility.
1394922_13_ITEM8_P119_S2	The Company s maximum contingent obligation on the outstanding warehouse balances at December 31, 2011 was approximately $661 thousand.
