1394922_16_ITEM6_P0_S0	A smaller reporting company is not required to present selected financial data in accordance with item 301(c) of Regulation S-K.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P0_S0	Statements contained in this Item 7, Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations ( MD A ) and elsewhere in this Form 10-K, which are not historical facts, may be forward-looking statements.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P0_S1	Such statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P0_S2	In particular, economic recession and changes in general economic conditions, including fluctuations in demand for equipment, lease rates, and interest rates, may result in delays in investment and reinvestment, delays in leasing, re-leasing, and disposition of equipment, and reduced returns on invested capital.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P0_S3	The Company s performance is subject to risks relating to lessee defaults and the creditworthiness of its lessees.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P0_S4	The Company s performance is also subject to risks relating to the value of its equipment at the end of its leases, which may be affected by the condition of the equipment, technological obsolescence and the markets for new and used equipment at the end of lease terms.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P1_S0	Investors are cautioned not to attribute undue certainty to these forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date of this Form 10-K. We undertake no obligation to publicly release any revisions to these forward-looking statements to reflect events or circumstances after the date of this Form 10-K or to reflect the occurrence of unanticipated events, other than as required by law.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P2_S0	ATEL 12, LLC (the Company or the Fund ) is a California limited liability company that was formed in January 2007 for the purpose of equipment financing and acquiring equipment to engage in equipment leasing and sales activities, as well as in real estate, growth capital investment activities and green technologies (the principal operations ), primarily in the United States.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P3_S0	The Company conducted a public offering of 20,000,000 Limited Liability Company Units ( Units ), at a price of $10 per Unit.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P3_S1	On January 24, 2008, subscriptions for the minimum number of Units (120,000, representing $1.2 million), excluding subscriptions from Pennsylvania investors, had been received and the Fund requested subscription proceeds to be released from escrow.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P3_S2	On that date, the Company commenced initial operations and continued in its development stage activities until transitioning to an operating enterprise during the second quarter of 2008.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P4_S0	Pennsylvania subscriptions were subject to a separate escrow to be released to the Fund only when the Fund had received aggregate subscriptions for all investors equal to at least $7.5 million.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P4_S1	Total contributions to the Fund exceeded $7.5 million on July 15, 2008.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P4_S2	As of September 25, 2009, the offering was terminated.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P5_S0	During 2009, the Company completed its initial acquisition stage with the investment of the net proceeds from the public offering of Units.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P5_S1	Subsequently, during the reinvestment period ( Reinvestment Period ) (defined as six full years following the year the offering was terminated), the Company has utilized its credit facilities and reinvested cash flow in excess of certain amounts required to be distributed to the Other Members to acquire additional equipment and/or to fund financing transactions.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P5_S2	Throughout the Reinvestment Period, which ends December 31, 2015, the Company anticipates continued reinvestment of cash flow in excess of minimum distributions and other obligations.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P6_S0	The Company is governed by its Limited Liability Company Operating Agreement ( Operating Agreement ), as amended.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P7_S0	The Company may continue until December 31, 2030.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P7_S1	However, pursuant to the guidelines of the Operating Agreement, the Company commenced liquidation phase activities on January 1, 2016.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P8_S0	Periodic distributions are paid at the discretion of the Managing Member.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P9_S0	As of December 31, 2015 and 2014, there were concentrations (greater than or equal to 10% as a percentage of total equipment cost) of equipment leased to lessees and/or financed for borrowers in certain industries as follows:
1394922_16_ITEM7_P10_S0	As previously mentioned, certain lessees and/or financial borrowers generated significant portions (defined as greater than or equal to 10%) of the Company s total leasing and lending revenues, excluding gains or losses on disposition of assets, during 2015 and 2014 as follows:
1394922_16_ITEM7_P11_S0	These percentages are not expected to be comparable in future periods due to anticipated changes in the mix of investments and/or lessees as a result of normal business activities.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P12_S0	It is the Company s objective to maintain a 100% utilization rate for all equipment purchased in any given year.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P12_S1	All equipment transactions are acquired subject to binding lease commitments, so equipment utilization is expected to remain high throughout the reinvestment stage.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P12_S2	Initial lease terms of these leases are generally from 36 to 120 months, and as they expire, the Company will attempt to re-lease or sell the equipment; as such, utilization rates may tend to decrease during the liquidation stage of the Company.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P12_S3	All of the Company s leased property was acquired during the period from 2008 to 2013.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P12_S4	The utilization percentage of existing assets under lease was 100% and 93% as of December 31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P13_S0	Cost reimbursements to the Managing Member are based on its costs incurred in performing administrative services for the Company.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P13_S1	These costs are allocated to each managed entity based on certain criteria such as total assets, number of investors or contributed capital based upon the type of cost incurred.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P14_S0	The Company had net income of $988 thousand and $894 thousand for the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P14_S1	Results for 2015 reflect decreases in both total revenues and total operating expenses when compared to prior year.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P15_S0	Total revenues for 2015 decreased by $1.4 million, or 34%, as compared to prior year.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P15_S1	Such decrease was largely attributable to reductions in operating lease revenues and gain on sales of lease assets and early termination of notes offset, in part, by an increase in gain on sales or dispositions of investment in securities.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P16_S0	The decrease in operating lease revenues totaled $1.1 million and was primarily attributable to run-off and sales of lease assets.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P16_S1	Gains recognized on sales of lease assets and early termination of notes declined by $411 thousand mainly due to a reduction in volume and change in the mix of assets sold, as the Fund sold two drill rigs associated with a terminated lease during the prior year period.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P17_S0	Partially offsetting the aforementioned decreases in revenues was a $117 thousand increase in gain on sales or dispositions of investment in securities.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P17_S1	Such increase was primarily due to a $147 thousand gain realized on the net exercise of warrants during the current year.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P18_S0	Total operating expenses for 2015 decreased by $1.5 million, or 46%, as compared to prior year.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P18_S1	The decrease was largely attributable to reductions in depreciation expense, impairment losses on equipment, cost reimbursements paid to the Managing Member and asset management fees offset, in part, by an increase in taxes on income and franchise fees.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P19_S0	The reduction in depreciation expense totaled $1.1 million and was largely a result of run-off and sales of lease assets.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P19_S1	Impairment losses on equipment declined by $226 thousand due to fair value adjustments recorded on certain impaired off-lease equipment during the prior year.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P19_S2	There was no such fair value adjustment during the current year.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P19_S3	Moreover, cost reimbursements paid to the Managing Member were reduced by $87 thousand as a result of lower allocated costs partially based on the Fund s declining asset base; and, asset management fees paid to the Managing Member decreased by $66 thousand as a result of the continued decline in managed assets and related rents.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P20_S0	The aforementioned decreases in expenses were partially offset by a $63 thousand increase in taxes on income and franchise fees.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P20_S1	Such increase was attributable to a higher estimated tax liability based upon a prior year increase in gains on sales of lease assets.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P21_S0	At both December 31, 2015 and 2014, the Company s cash and cash equivalents totaled $2.3 million.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P21_S1	The liquidity of the Company varies, increasing to the extent cash flows from leases and proceeds of asset sales exceed expenses and decreasing as lease assets are acquired, as distributions are made to the Members and to the extent expenses exceed cash flows from leases and proceeds from asset sales.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P22_S0	The primary source of liquidity for the Company has been its cash flow from fixed-term leasing activities.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P22_S1	As the lease terms expire, the Company will re-lease or sell the equipment.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P22_S2	The future liquidity beyond the contractual minimum rentals will depend on the Company s success in remarketing or selling the equipment as it comes off rental.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P23_S0	The Company currently believes it has available adequate reserves to meet its immediate cash requirements and those of the next twelve months, but in the event those reserves were found to be inadequate, the Company would likely be in a position to borrow against its current portfolio to meet such requirements.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P23_S1	The Managing Member envisions no such requirements for operating purposes.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P24_S0	The following table sets forth summary cash flow data (in thousands):
1394922_16_ITEM7_P25_S0	During 2015 and 2014, the Company s primary sources of liquidity were cash flows from its portfolio of operating and direct financing lease contracts, and its investments in notes receivable.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P25_S1	Moreover, the Company realized $1.5 million and $3.0 million of proceeds from the sales of lease assets and/or the early termination of notes receivable during the respective years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P25_S2	In addition, during the prior year, the Company utilized borrowings totaling $197 thousand.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P26_S0	During the same comparative years, cash was primarily used to pay distributions to both the Other Members and the Managing Member and to pay down debt.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P26_S1	Total distributions paid to Members amounted to $2.9 million for each of 2015 and 2014; while cash used to pay down debt totaled $873 thousand and $2.3 million for 2015 and 2014, respectively.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P27_S0	Effective December 30, 2014, the Company s participation in a revolving credit facility with AFS and certain of its affiliates was terminated.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P27_S1	The Company had no related balances outstanding at the time.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P28_S0	Prior to December 30, 2014, the Company participated with AFS and certain of its affiliates in a revolving credit facility comprised of a working capital facility to AFS, an acquisition facility and a warehouse facility to AFS, the Company and affiliates, and a venture facility available to an affiliate, with a syndicate of financial institutions as lenders.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P29_S0	As of December 31, 2015 and 2014, the Company had non-recourse long-term debt totaling $1.0 million and $1.9 million, respectively.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P29_S1	Such non-recourse notes payable do not contain any material financial covenants.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P29_S2	The notes are secured by a lien granted by the Company to the non-recourse lenders on (and only on) the discounted lease transactions.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P29_S3	The lenders have recourse only to the following collateral: the specific leased equipment; the related lease chattel paper; the lease receivables; and proceeds of the foregoing items.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P30_S0	For detailed information on the Company s debt obligations, see Notes 8 and 9 to the financial statements as set forth in Part II, Item 8, Financial Statements and Supplementary Data.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P31_S0	The Company commenced periodic distributions, based on cash flows from operations, beginning with the month of February 2008.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P31_S1	Such distributions have been consistently made through December 31, 2015.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P31_S2	See Item 5, Market for Registrant s Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities, for additional information regarding the distributions.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P32_S0	At December 31, 2015, the Company had no commitments to purchase lease assets or fund investments in notes receivable.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P33_S0	In May 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers ( ASU 2014-09 ), which amends the existing accounting standards for revenue recognition.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P33_S1	ASU 2014-09 is based on principles that govern the recognition of revenue at an amount an entity expects to be entitled when products are transferred to customers.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P33_S2	On July 9, 2015, the FASB approved the deferral of the effective date of ASU 2014-09 by one year and in August 2015, issued Revenue from Contracts from Customers (Topic 606): Deferral of the Effective Date ( ASU 2015-14 ).
1394922_16_ITEM7_P33_S3	ASU 2015-14 is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2017, including interim periods within that reporting period.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P33_S4	Earlier application is permitted only as of annual reporting periods beginning after December 31, 2016, including interim reporting periods within that reporting period.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P33_S5	The new revenue standard may be applied retrospectively to each prior period presented or retrospectively with the cumulative effect recognized as of the date of adoption.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P33_S6	The Company evaluated the impact of the new standard on its financial statements and has determined that such impact is virtually non-existent as the new revenue guideline does not affect revenues from leases and loans, which comprise the majority of the Company s revenues.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P34_S0	In August 2014, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update 2014-15, Presentation of Financial Statements Going Concern (subtopic 205-40): Disclosure of Uncertainties about an Entity s Ability to Continue as a Going Concern ( ASU-2014-15 ).
1394922_16_ITEM7_P34_S1	The new standard provides guidance relative to management s responsibility to evaluate whether there is substantial doubt about an entity s ability to continue as a going concern and to provide related footnote disclosures.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P34_S2	The new standard is effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those fiscal years, beginning after December 15, 2016.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P34_S3	Management does not expect the adoption of ASU 2014-15 to have a material impact on the Company s financial statements or related disclosures.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P35_S0	The policies discussed below are considered by management of the Company to be critical to an understanding of the Company s financial statements because their application requires significantly complex or subjective judgments, decisions, or assessments, with financial reporting results relying on estimation about the effect of matters that are inherently uncertain.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P35_S1	Specific risks for these critical accounting policies are described in the following paragraphs.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P36_S0	Company also states these accounting policies in the notes to the financial statements and in relevant sections in this discussion and analysis.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P36_S1	For all of these policies, management cautions that future events rarely develop exactly as forecast, and the best estimates routinely require adjustment.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P37_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P37_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P37_S2	Such estimates primarily relate to the determination of residual values at the end of the lease term and expected future cash flows used for impairment analysis purposes and for determination of the allowance for doubtful accounts and reserve for credit losses on notes receivable.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P38_S0	Equipment on operating leases and related revenue recognition:
1394922_16_ITEM7_P39_S0	Equipment subject to operating leases is stated at cost.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P39_S1	Depreciation is being recognized on a straight-line method over the terms of the related leases to the equipment s estimated residual values.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P39_S2	Off-lease equipment is generally not subject to depreciation.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P39_S3	The Company depreciates all lease assets, in accordance with guidelines consistent with ASC 840-20-35-3, over the periods of the lease terms contained in each asset s respective lease contract to the estimated residual value at the end of the lease contract.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P39_S4	All lease assets are purchased only concurrent with the execution of a lease commitment by the lessee.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P39_S5	Thus, the original depreciation period corresponds with the term of the original lease.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P40_S0	Once the term of an original lease contract is completed, the subject property is typically sold to the existing user, re-leased to the existing user, or, when off-lease, is held for sale.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P40_S1	Assets which are re-leased continue to be depreciated using the terms of the new lease agreements and the estimated residual values at the end of the new lease terms, adjusted downward as necessary.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P41_S0	Assets classified as held-for-sale are carried at the lower of carrying amount, or the fair value less cost to sell (ASC 360-10-35-43).
1394922_16_ITEM7_P42_S0	The Company does not use the equipment held in its portfolio, but holds it solely for lease and ultimate sale.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P42_S1	In the course of marketing equipment that has come off-lease, management may determine at some point that re-leasing the assets may provide a superior return for investors and would then execute another lease.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P42_S2	Upon entering into a new lease contract, management will estimate the residual value once again and resume depreciation.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P43_S0	If, and when, the Company, at any time, determines that depreciation in value may have occurred with respect to an asset held-for-sale, the Company would review the value to determine whether a material reduction in value had occurred and recognize any appropriate impairment.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P43_S1	All lease assets, including off-lease assets, are subject to the Company s quarterly impairment analysis, as described below.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P43_S2	Maintenance costs associated with the Fund s portfolio of leased assets are expensed as incurred.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P43_S3	Major additions and betterments are capitalized.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P44_S0	Operating lease revenue is recognized on a straight-line basis over the term of the underlying leases.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P44_S1	The initial lease terms will vary as to the type of equipment subject to the leases, the needs of the lessees and the terms to be negotiated, but initial leases are generally on terms from 36 to 120 months.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P44_S2	The difference between rent received and rental revenue recognized is recorded as unearned operating lease income on the balance sheet.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P45_S0	Operating leases are generally placed in a non-accrual status (i.e., no revenue is recognized) when payments are more than 90 days past due.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P45_S1	Additionally, management considers the equipment underlying the lease contracts for impairment and periodically reviews the credit worthiness of all operating lessees with payments outstanding less than 90 days.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P45_S2	Based upon management s judgment, the related operating leases may be placed on non-accrual status.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P45_S3	Leases placed on non-accrual status are only returned to an accrual status when the account has been brought current and management believes recovery of the remaining unpaid lease payments is probable.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P45_S4	Until such time, revenues are recognized on a cash basis.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P46_S0	Recorded values of the Company s leased asset portfolio are reviewed each quarter to confirm the reasonableness of established residual values and to determine whether there is indication that an asset impairment might have taken place.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P46_S1	The Company uses a variety of sources and considers many factors in evaluating whether the respective book values of its assets are appropriate.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P46_S2	In addition, the company may direct a residual value review at any time if it becomes aware of issues regarding the ability of a lessee to continue to make payments on its lease contract.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P46_S3	An impairment loss is measured and recognized only if the estimated undiscounted future cash flows of the asset are less than their net book value.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P46_S4	The estimated undiscounted future cash flows are the sum of the residual value of the asset at the end of the asset s lease contract and undiscounted future rents from the existing lease contract.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P46_S5	The residual value assumes, among other things, that the asset is utilized normally in an open, unrestricted and stable market.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P46_S6	Short-term fluctuations in the marketplace are disregarded and it is assumed that there is no necessity either to dispose of a significant number of the assets, if held in quantity, simultaneously or to dispose of the asset quickly.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P47_S0	is measured as the difference between the fair value (as determined by a valuation method using discounted estimated future cash flows, third party appraisals or comparable sales of similar assets as applicable based on asset type) of the asset and its carrying value on the measurement date.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P47_S1	Upward adjustments for impairments recognized in prior periods are not made in any circumstances.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P48_S0	Direct financing leases and related revenue recognition:
1394922_16_ITEM7_P49_S0	Income from direct financing lease transactions is reported using the financing method of accounting, in which the Company s investment in the leased property is reported as a receivable from the lessee to be recovered through future rentals.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P49_S1	The interest income portion of each rental payment is calculated so as to generate a constant rate of return on the net receivable outstanding.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P50_S0	Allowances for losses on direct financing leases are typically established based on historical charge-off and collection experience and the collectability of specifically identified lessees and billed and unbilled receivables.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P50_S1	Direct financing leases are charged off to the allowance as they are deemed uncollectible.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P51_S0	Direct financing leases are generally placed in a non-accrual status (i.e., no revenue is recognized) and deemed impaired when payments are more than 90 days past due.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P51_S1	Additionally, management periodically reviews the creditworthiness of all direct finance lessees with payments outstanding less than 90 days.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P51_S2	Based upon management s judgment, the related direct financing leases may be placed on non-accrual status.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P51_S3	Leases placed on non-accrual status are only returned to an accrual status when the account has been brought current and management believes recovery of the remaining unpaid lease payments is probable.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P51_S4	Until such time, all payments received are applied only against outstanding principal balances.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P52_S0	Notes receivable, unearned interest income and related revenue recognition:
1394922_16_ITEM7_P53_S0	The Company records all future payments of principal and interest on notes as notes receivable, which are then offset by the amount of any related unearned interest income.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P53_S1	For financial statement purposes, the Company reports only the net amount of principal due on the balance sheet.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P53_S2	The unearned interest is recognized over the term of the note and the income portion of each note payment is calculated so as to generate a constant rate of return on the net balance outstanding.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P53_S3	Any fees or costs related to notes receivable are recorded as part of the net investment in notes receivable and amortized over the term of the loan.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P54_S0	Allowances for losses on notes receivable are typically established based on historical charge-off and collection experience and the collectability of specifically identified borrowers and billed and unbilled receivables.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P54_S1	Notes are considered impaired when, based on current information and events, it is probable that the Company will be unable to collect the scheduled payments of principal and/or interest when due according to the contractual terms of the note agreement.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P54_S2	Factors considered by management in determining impairment include payment status, collateral value, and the probability of collecting scheduled principal and interest when due.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P54_S3	If it is determined that a loan is impaired with regard to scheduled payments, the Company will perform an analysis of the note to determine if an impairment valuation reserve is necessary.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P54_S4	This analysis considers the estimated cash flows from the note, or the collateral value of the property underlying the note when note repayment is collateral dependent.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P54_S5	Any required valuation reserve is charged to earnings when determined; and notes are charged off to the allowance as they are deemed uncollectible.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P55_S0	Notes receivable are generally placed in a non-accrual status (i.e., no revenue is recognized) when payments are more than 90 days past due.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P55_S1	Additionally, management periodically reviews the creditworthiness of companies with note payments outstanding less than 90 days.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P55_S2	Based upon management s judgment, notes may be placed in a non-accrual status.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P55_S3	Notes placed on non-accrual status are only returned to an accrual status when the account has been brought current and management believes recovery of the remaining unpaid receivable is probable.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P55_S4	Until such time, all payments received are applied only against outstanding principal balances.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P56_S0	The Company capitalizes initial direct costs ( IDC ) associated with the origination and funding of lease assets and investments in notes receivable.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P56_S1	IDC includes both internal costs (e.g., the costs of employees activities in connection with successful lease and loan originations) and external broker fees incurred with such originations.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P56_S2	The costs are amortized on a lease by lease (or note by note) basis based on actual contract term using a straight-line method for operating leases and the effective interest rate method for direct financing leases and notes receivable.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P56_S3	Upon disposal of the underlying lease or loan assets, both the initial direct costs and the associated accumulated amortization are relieved.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P56_S4	Costs related to leases or notes receivable that are not consummated are not eligible for capitalization as initial direct costs and are expensed as acquisition expense.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P57_S0	Recorded values of the Company s leased asset portfolio are periodically reviewed for impairment.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P57_S1	An impairment loss is measured and recognized only if the estimated undiscounted future cash flows of the asset are less than their net book value.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P57_S2	The estimated undiscounted future cash flows are the sum of the estimated residual value of the asset at the end of the asset s expected holding period and estimates of undiscounted future rents.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P57_S3	The residual value assumes, among other things, that the asset is utilized normally in an open, unrestricted and stable market.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P57_S4	Short-term fluctuations in the market place are disregarded and it is assumed that there is no necessity either to dispose of a significant number of the assets, if held in quantity, simultaneously or to dispose of the asset quickly.
1394922_16_ITEM7_P58_S0	Impairment is measured as the difference between the fair value (as determined by a valuation method using discounted estimated future cash flows, third party appraisals or comparable sales of similar assets as applicable based on asset type) of the assets and its carrying value on the measurement date.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P0_S0	See the Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm, Financial Statements and Notes to Financial Statements attached hereto at pages 14 through 36 .
1394922_16_ITEM8_P1_S0	We have audited the accompanying balance sheets of ATEL 12, LLC (the Company ) as of December 31, 2015 and 2014, and the related statements of income, changes in members capital, and cash flows for the years then ended.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P1_S1	These financial statements are the responsibility of the Management of the Company s Managing Member.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P1_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P2_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1394922_16_ITEM8_P2_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P2_S2	The Company is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform, an audit of its internal control over financial reporting.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P2_S3	Our audits included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P2_S4	Accordingly, we express no such opinion.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P3_S0	An audit also includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P3_S1	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P4_S0	In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of ATEL 12, LLC as of December 31, 2015 and 2014, and the results of its operations and its cash flows for the years then ended, in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P5_S0	Organization and Limited Liability Company matters:
1394922_16_ITEM8_P6_S0	ATEL 12, LLC (the Company or the Fund ) was formed under the laws of the state of California on January 25, 2007 for the purpose of equipment financing and acquiring equipment to engage in equipment leasing and sales activities, as well as in real estate, growth capital investment activities and green technologies (the principal operations ).
1394922_16_ITEM8_P6_S1	From its inception into the third quarter of 2013, the Company s Managing Member was ATEL Associates 12, LLC ( AA12 ), a Nevada limited liability corporation.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P6_S2	Effective September 30, 2013, AA12 was merged into ATEL Financial Services, LLC ( AFS ) (the Managing Member or Manager ), a California limited liability corporation, which assumed the role of Managing Member of the Company.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P6_S3	The Fund may continue until December 31, 2030.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P7_S0	As a limited liability company, the liability of any individual member for the obligations of the Fund is limited to the extent of capital contributions to the Fund by the individual member.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P8_S0	The Company conducted a public offering of 20,000,000 Limited Liability Company Units ( Units ), at a price of $10 per Unit.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P8_S1	On January 24, 2008, subscriptions for the minimum number of Units (120,000, representing $1.2 million), excluding subscriptions from Pennsylvania investors, had been received and the Fund requested subscription proceeds to be released from escrow.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P8_S2	On that date, the Company commenced initial operations and continued in its development stage activities until transitioning to an operating enterprise during the second quarter of 2008.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P9_S0	Pennsylvania subscriptions were subject to a separate escrow to be released to the Fund only when the Fund had received aggregate subscriptions for all investors equal to at least $7.5 million.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P9_S1	Total contributions to the Fund exceeded $7.5 million on July 15, 2008.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P9_S2	The offering was terminated on September 25, 2009.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P10_S0	As of December 31, 2015, cumulative contributions, net of rescissions and/or redemptions, totaling $29.9 million (inclusive of the $500 initial Member s capital investment) have been received and 2,992,482 Units were issued and outstanding.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P11_S0	The Fund, or Managing Member and/or affiliates on behalf of the Fund, has incurred costs in connection with the organization, registration and issuance of the Units.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P11_S1	The amount of such costs to be borne by the Fund is limited by certain provisions of the ATEL 12, LLC Limited Liability Company Operating Agreement dated April 3, 2007 (the Operating Agreement ).
1394922_16_ITEM8_P12_S0	The Company s principal objectives are to invest in a diversified portfolio of investments that (i) preserves, protects and returns the Company s invested capital; (ii) generates regular cash distributions to Unitholders, any balance remaining after required minimum distributions to be used to purchase additional investments during the Reinvestment Period (ending six calendar years after the completion of the Company s public offering of Units) which ends on December 31, 2015 and (iii) provides additional cash distributions following the Reinvestment Period and until all investment portfolio assets have been sold or otherwise disposed.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P13_S0	The Company is governed by its Operating Agreement, as amended.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P14_S0	On January 1, 2016, the Company commenced liquidation phase activities pursuant to the guidelines of the Operating Agreement.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P14_S1	Prior thereto, the Company was in its acquisition phase and was making distributions on a monthly and quarterly basis.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P14_S2	During the liquidation phase, periodic distributions are paid at the discretion of the Managing Member.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P15_S0	The accompanying balance sheets as of December 31, 2015 and 2014, and the related statements of income, changes in members capital, and cash flows for the years then ended, have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( GAAP ) and the rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P15_S1	Certain prior year amounts have been reclassified to conform to the current year presentation.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P15_S2	These reclassifications had no significant effect on the reported financial position or results of operations.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P16_S0	Footnote and tabular amounts are presented in thousands, except as to Units and per Unit data.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P17_S0	In preparing the accompanying financial statements, the Company has reviewed, as determined necessary by the Managing Member, events that have occurred after December 31, 2015, up until the issuance of the financial statements.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P17_S1	No events were noted which would require disclosure in the footnotes to the financial statements.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P18_S0	Cash and cash equivalents include cash in banks and cash equivalent investments such as U.S. Treasury instruments with original and/or purchased maturities of ninety days or less.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P19_S0	The preparation of the financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P19_S1	Actual results could differ from the estimates.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P19_S2	Such estimates primarily relate to the determination of residual values at the end of the lease term and expected future cash flows used for impairment analysis purposes and determination of the allowances for doubtful accounts and reserve for credit losses on notes receivable.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P20_S0	Accounts receivable represent the amounts billed under operating and direct financing lease contracts, and notes receivable which are currently due to the Company.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P20_S1	Allowances for doubtful accounts are typically established based on historical charge off and collection experience and the collectability of specifically identified lessees and borrowers, and invoiced amounts.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P20_S2	Accounts receivable deemed uncollectible are generally charged off against the allowance on a specific identification basis.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P21_S0	Recoveries of amounts that were previously written-off are recorded as other income in the period received.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P22_S0	Financial instruments that potentially subject the Company to concentrations of credit risk include cash and cash equivalents, operating and direct financing lease receivables, notes receivable and accounts receivable.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P22_S1	The Company places the majority of its cash deposits in noninterest-bearing accounts with financial institutions that have no less than $10 billion in assets.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P22_S2	Such deposits are insured up to $250 thousand.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P22_S3	The remainder of the Funds cash is temporarily invested in U.S. Treasury denominated instruments.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P22_S4	The concentration of such deposits and temporary cash investments is not deemed to create a significant risk to the Company.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P23_S0	Accounts and notes receivable represent amounts due from lessees or borrowers in various industries, related to equipment on operating and direct financing leases or notes receivable.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P24_S0	Equipment on operating leases and related revenue recognition:
1394922_16_ITEM8_P25_S0	Equipment subject to operating leases is stated at cost.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P25_S1	Depreciation is being recognized on a straight-line method over the terms of the related leases to the equipment s estimated residual values.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P25_S2	Off-lease equipment is generally not subject to depreciation.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P25_S3	The Company depreciates all lease assets, in accordance with guidelines consistent with ASC 840-20-35-3, over the periods of the lease terms contained in each asset s respective lease contract to the estimated residual value at the end of the lease contract.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P25_S4	All lease assets are purchased only concurrent with the execution of a lease commitment by the lessee.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P25_S5	Thus, the original depreciation period corresponds with the term of the original lease.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P26_S0	Once the term of an original lease contract is completed, the subject property is typically sold to the existing user, re-leased to the existing user, or, when off-lease, is held for sale.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P26_S1	Assets which are re-leased continue to be depreciated using the terms of the new lease agreements and the estimated residual values at the end of the new lease terms, adjusted downward as necessary.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P27_S0	Assets classified as held-for-sale are carried at the lower of carrying amount, or the fair value less cost to sell (ASC 360-10-35-43).
1394922_16_ITEM8_P28_S0	The Company does not use the equipment held in its portfolio, but holds it solely for lease and ultimate sale.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P28_S1	In the course of marketing equipment that has come off-lease, management may determine at some point that re-leasing the assets may provide a superior return for investors and would then execute another lease.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P28_S2	Upon entering into a new lease contract, management will estimate the residual value once again and resume depreciation.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P29_S0	All lease assets, including off-lease assets, are subject to the Company s quarterly impairment analysis, as described below.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P29_S1	Maintenance costs associated with the Fund s portfolio of leased assets are expensed as incurred.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P29_S2	Major additions and betterments are capitalized.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P30_S0	Operating lease revenue is recognized on a straight-line basis over the term of the underlying leases.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P30_S1	The initial lease terms will vary as to the type of equipment subject to the leases, the needs of the lessees and the terms to be negotiated, but initial leases are generally on terms from 36 to 120 months.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P30_S2	The difference between rent received and rental revenue recognized is recorded as unearned operating lease income on the balance sheet.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P31_S0	Operating leases are generally placed in a non-accrual status (i.e., no revenue is recognized) when payments are more than 90 days past due.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P31_S1	Additionally, management considers the equipment underlying the lease contracts for impairment and periodically reviews the credit worthiness of all operating lessees with payments outstanding less than 90 days.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P31_S2	Based upon management s judgment, the related operating leases may be placed on non-accrual status.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P31_S3	Leases placed on non-accrual status are only returned to an accrual status when the account has been brought current and management believes recovery of the remaining unpaid lease payments is probable.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P31_S4	Until such time, revenues are recognized on a cash basis.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P32_S0	Recorded values of the Company s leased asset portfolio are reviewed each quarter to confirm the reasonableness of established residual values and to determine whether there is indication that an asset impairment might have taken place.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P32_S1	The Company uses a variety of sources and considers many factors in evaluating whether the respective book values of its assets are appropriate.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P32_S2	In addition, the company may direct a residual value review at any time if it becomes aware of issues regarding the ability of a lessee to continue to make payments on its lease contract.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P32_S3	An impairment loss is measured and recognized only if the estimated undiscounted future cash flows of the asset are less than their net book value.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P32_S4	The estimated undiscounted future cash flows are the sum of the residual value of the asset at the end of the asset s lease contract and undiscounted future rents from the existing lease contract.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P32_S5	The residual value assumes, among other things, that the asset is utilized normally in an open, unrestricted and stable market.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P32_S6	Short-term fluctuations in the marketplace are disregarded and it is assumed that there is no necessity either to dispose of a significant number of the assets, if held in quantity, simultaneously or to dispose of the asset quickly.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P33_S0	Impairment is measured as the difference between the fair value (as determined by a valuation method using discounted estimated future cash flows, third party appraisals or comparable sales of similar assets as applicable based on asset type) of the asset and its carrying value on the measurement date.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P33_S1	Upward adjustments for impairments recognized in prior periods are not made in any circumstances.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P34_S0	Direct financing leases and related revenue recognition:
1394922_16_ITEM8_P35_S0	Income from direct financing lease transactions is reported using the financing method of accounting, in which the Company s investment in the leased property is reported as a receivable from the lessee to be recovered through future rentals.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P35_S1	The interest income portion of each rental payment is calculated so as to generate a constant rate of return on the net receivable outstanding.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P36_S0	Allowances for losses on direct financing leases are typically established based on historical charge-off and collection experience and the collectability of specifically identified lessees and billed and unbilled receivables.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P36_S1	Direct financing leases are charged off to the allowance as they are deemed uncollectible.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P37_S0	Direct financing leases are generally placed in a non-accrual status (i.e., no revenue is recognized) and deemed impaired when payments are more than 90 days past due.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P37_S1	Additionally, management periodically reviews the creditworthiness of all direct finance lessees with payments outstanding less than 90 days.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P37_S2	Based upon management s judgment, the related direct financing leases may be placed on non-accrual status.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P37_S3	Leases placed on non-accrual status are only returned to an accrual status when the account has been brought current and management believes recovery of the remaining unpaid lease payments is probable.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P37_S4	Until such time, all payments received are applied only against outstanding principal balances.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P38_S0	Notes receivable, unearned interest income and related revenue recognition:
1394922_16_ITEM8_P39_S0	The Company records all future payments of principal and interest on notes as notes receivable, which are then offset by the amount of any related unearned interest income.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P39_S1	For financial statement purposes, the Company reports only the net amount of principal due on the balance sheet.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P39_S2	The unearned interest is recognized over the term of the note and the income portion of each note payment is calculated so as to generate a constant rate of return on the net balance outstanding.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P39_S3	Any fees or costs related to notes receivable are recorded as part of the net investment in notes receivable and amortized over the term of the loan.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P40_S0	Allowances for losses on notes receivable are typically established based on historical charge off and collection experience and the collectability of specifically identified borrowers and billed and unbilled receivables.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P40_S1	Notes are considered impaired when, based on current information and events, it is probable that the Company will be unable to collect the scheduled payments of principal and/or interest when due according to the contractual terms of the note agreement.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P40_S2	Factors considered by management in determining impairment include payment status, collateral value, and the probability of collecting scheduled principal and interest when due.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P40_S3	If it is determined that a loan is impaired with regard to scheduled payments, the Company will perform an analysis of the note to determine if an impairment valuation reserve is necessary.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P40_S4	This analysis considers the estimated cash flows from the note, or the collateral value of the property underlying the note when note repayment is collateral dependent.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P40_S5	Any required valuation reserve is charged to earnings when determined; and notes are charged off to the allowance as they are deemed uncollectible.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P41_S0	Notes receivable are generally placed in a non-accrual status (i.e., no revenue is recognized) when payments are more than 90 days past due.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P41_S1	Additionally, management periodically reviews the creditworthiness of companies with note payments outstanding less than 90 days.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P41_S2	Based upon management s judgment, notes may be placed in a non-accrual status.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P41_S3	Notes placed on non-accrual status are only returned to an accrual status when the account has been brought current and management believes recovery of the remaining unpaid receivable is probable.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P41_S4	Until such time, all payments received are applied only against outstanding principal balances.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P42_S0	The Company capitalizes initial direct costs ( IDC ) associated with the origination and funding of lease assets and investments in notes receivable.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P42_S1	IDC includes both internal costs (e.g., the costs of employees activities in connection with successful lease and loan originations) and external broker fees incurred with such originations.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P42_S2	The costs are amortized on a lease by lease (or note by note) basis based on actual lease term using a straight-line method for operating leases and the effective interest rate method for direct financing leases and notes receivable.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P42_S3	Upon disposal of the underlying lease or loan assets, both the initial direct costs and the associated accumulated amortization are relieved.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P42_S4	Costs related to leases or notes receivable that are not consummated are not eligible for capitalization as initial direct costs and are expensed as acquisition expense.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P43_S0	Acquisition expense represents costs which include, but are not limited to, legal fees and expenses, travel and communication expenses, cost of appraisals, accounting fees and expenses and miscellaneous expenses related to the selection and acquisition of equipment which are reimbursable to the Managing Member under the terms of the Operating Agreement.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P43_S1	As the costs are not eligible for capitalization as initial direct costs, such amounts are expensed as incurred.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P44_S0	Recorded values of the Company s leased asset portfolio are periodically reviewed for impairment.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P44_S1	An impairment loss is measured and recognized only if the estimated undiscounted future cash flows of the asset are less than their net book value.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P44_S2	The estimated undiscounted future cash flows are the sum of the estimated residual value of the asset at the end of the asset s expected holding period and estimates of undiscounted future rents.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P44_S3	The residual value assumes, among other things, that the asset is utilized normally in an open, unrestricted and stable market.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P45_S0	significant number of the assets, if held in quantity, simultaneously or to dispose of the asset quickly.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P46_S0	Impairment is measured as the difference between the fair value (as determined by a valuation method using discounted estimated future cash flows, third party appraisals or comparable sales of similar assets as applicable based on asset type) of the asset and its carrying value on the measurement date.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P47_S0	The Company is organized into one operating segment for the purpose of making operating decisions or assessing performance.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P47_S1	Accordingly, the Company operates in one reportable operating segment in the United States.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P48_S0	The Company s principal decision makers are the Managing Member s Chief Executive Officer and its Chief Financial Officer and Chief Operating Officer.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P48_S1	The Company believes that its equipment leasing business operates as one reportable segment because: a) the Company measures profit and loss at the equipment portfolio level as a whole; b) the principal decision makers do not review information based on any operating segment other than the equipment leasing transaction portfolio; c) the Company does not maintain discrete financial information on any specific segment other than its equipment financing operations; d) the Company has not chosen to organize its business around different products and services other than equipment lease financing; and e) the Company has not chosen to organize its business around geographic areas.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P49_S0	The primary geographic regions in which the Company sought leasing opportunities were North America and Europe.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P49_S1	For the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014, and as of December 31, 2015 and 2014, 100% of the Company s operating revenues and long-lived assets are from customers domiciled in North America.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P50_S0	Purchased securities are generally not registered for public sale and are carried at cost.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P50_S1	Such securities are adjusted to fair value if the fair value is less than the carrying value and such impairment is deemed by the Managing Member to be other than temporary.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P51_S0	Factors considered by the Managing Member in determining fair value include, but are not limited to, available financial information, the issuer s ability to meet its current obligations and indications of the issuer s subsequent ability to raise capital.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P51_S1	Based upon the Company s review of its portfolio, a fair value adjustment of $6 thousand was recorded during 2015 relative to an impaired investment.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P51_S2	No such fair value adjustment was deemed necessary for the year ended December 31, 2014.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P51_S3	Purchased securities totaled $300 thousand and $258 thousand at December 31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P51_S4	Gains recognized on sales or dispositions of investment securities totaled $14 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2014.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P51_S5	There were no sales or dispositions of securities during 2015.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P52_S0	Warrants owned by the Company are not registered for public sale, but are considered derivatives and are reflected at an estimated fair value on the balance sheet at the end of the period, as determined by the Managing Member.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P52_S1	During 2015 and 2014, the Company recorded unrealized losses of $66 thousand and $162 thousand, respectively, on fair valuation of its warrants.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P52_S2	As of December 31, 2015 and 2014, the Company s portfolio of warrants had an estimated fair value of $327 thousand and $393 thousand, respectively.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P52_S3	During 2015 and 2014, the Company realized gains of $147 thousand and $16 thousand, respectively, on the net exercise of certain warrants.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P53_S0	The Company records prepayments on operating leases as a liability under the caption of unearned operating lease income.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P53_S1	The liability is recorded when prepayments are received and recognized as operating lease revenue over the period to which the prepayments relate using a straight-line method.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P54_S0	The Company is treated as a partnership for federal income tax purposes.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P54_S1	Pursuant to the provisions of Section 701 of the Internal Revenue Code, a partnership is not subject to federal income taxes.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P54_S2	Accordingly, the Company has provided current franchise income taxes for only those states which levy income taxes on partnerships.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P54_S3	For the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014, the related provision for state income taxes was approximately $64 thousand and $1 thousand, respectively.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P54_S4	The Company does not have any entity level uncertain tax positions.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P55_S0	The Company files income tax returns in the U.S. federal jurisdiction and various state jurisdictions and is generally subject to examination by U.S. federal (or state and local) income tax authorities for three years from the filing of a tax return.

1394922_16_ITEM8_P57_S0	The primary differences between the tax bases of net assets and the amounts recorded in the financial statements are the result of differences in accounting for impairment losses, syndication costs and differences between the depreciation methods used in the financial statements and the Company s tax returns.

1394922_16_ITEM8_P59_S0	Net income and distributions per Unit are based upon the weighted average number of Other Members Units outstanding during the year.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P60_S0	In May 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers ( ASU 2014-09 ), which amends the existing accounting standards for revenue recognition.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P60_S1	ASU 2014-09 is based on principles that govern the recognition of revenue at an amount an entity expects to be entitled when products are transferred to customers.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P60_S2	On July 9, 2015, the FASB approved the deferral of the effective date of ASU 2014-09 by one year and in August 2015, issued Revenue from Contracts from Customers (Topic 606): Deferral of the Effective Date ( ASU 2015-14 ).
1394922_16_ITEM8_P60_S3	ASU 2015-14 is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2017, including interim periods within that reporting period.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P60_S4	Earlier application is permitted only as of annual reporting periods beginning after December 31, 2016, including interim reporting periods within that reporting period.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P61_S0	or retrospectively with the cumulative effect recognized as of the date of adoption.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P61_S1	The Company evaluated the impact of the new standard on its financial statements and has determined that such impact is virtually non-existent as the new revenue guideline does not affect revenues from leases and loans, which comprise the majority of the Company s revenues.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P62_S0	In August 2014, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update 2014-15, Presentation of Financial Statements Going Concern (subtopic 205-40): Disclosure of Uncertainties about an Entity s Ability to Continue as a Going Concern ( ASU-2014-15 ).
1394922_16_ITEM8_P62_S1	The new standard provides guidance relative to management s responsibility to evaluate whether there is substantial doubt about an entity s ability to continue as a going concern and to provide related footnote disclosures.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P62_S2	The new standard is effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those fiscal years, beginning after December 15, 2016.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P62_S3	Management does not expect the adoption of ASU 2014-15 to have a material impact on the Company s financial statements or related disclosures.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P63_S0	Concentration of credit risk and major customers:
1394922_16_ITEM8_P64_S0	The Company leases equipment to lessees and provides debt financing to borrowers in diversified industries.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P64_S1	Leases and notes receivable are subject to the Managing Member s credit committee review.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P64_S2	The leases and notes receivable provide for the return of the equipment to the Company upon default.

1394922_16_ITEM8_P67_S1	At December 31, 2015, the terms of the notes receivable are from 36 to 42 months and bear interest at rates ranging from 11.88% to 14.30% per annum.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P67_S2	The notes are secured by the equipment financed and have maturity dates ranging from 2016 through 2017.

1394922_16_ITEM8_P69_S0	IDC amortization expense related to notes receivable and the Company s operating and direct financing leases for the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014 are as follows (in thousands):
1394922_16_ITEM8_P70_S0	The Company s allowance for credit losses are as follows (in thousands):
1394922_16_ITEM8_P71_S0	Accounts receivable represent the amounts billed under operating and direct financing lease contracts, and notes receivable which are currently due to the Company.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P72_S0	Allowances for doubtful accounts are typically established based upon their aging and historical charge off and collection experience and the creditworthiness of specifically identified lessees and borrowers, and invoiced amounts.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P72_S1	Accounts receivable deemed uncollectible are generally charged off against the allowance on a specific identification basis.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P73_S0	Recoveries of amounts that were previously written-off are recorded as other income in the period received.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P74_S0	Accounts receivable are generally placed in a non-accrual status (i.e., no revenue is recognized) when payments are more than 90 days past due.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P74_S1	Additionally, management periodically reviews the creditworthiness of companies with lease or note payments outstanding less than 90 days.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P74_S2	Based upon management s judgment, such leases or notes may be placed in non-accrual status.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P74_S3	Leases or notes placed on non-accrual status are only returned to an accrual status when the account has been brought current and management believes recovery of the remaining unpaid receivable is probable.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P74_S4	Until such time, revenues on operating leases are recognized on a cash basis.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P74_S5	All payments received on amounts billed under direct financing leases contracts and notes receivable are applied only against outstanding principal balances.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P75_S0	In addition to the allowance established for delinquent accounts receivable, the total allowance related solely to financing receivables also includes anticipated impairment charges on notes receivable and direct financing leases.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P76_S0	Notes are considered impaired when, based on current information and events, it is probable that the Company will be unable to collect the scheduled payments of principal and/or interest when due according to the contractual terms of the note agreement.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P76_S1	Factors considered by management in determining impairment include payment status, collateral value, and the probability of collecting scheduled principal and interest when due.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P76_S2	If it is determined that a loan is impaired with regard to scheduled payments, the Company will perform an analysis of the note to determine if an impairment valuation reserve is necessary.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P76_S3	This analysis considers the estimated cash flows from the note, or the collateral value of the property underlying the note when note repayment is collateral dependent.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P76_S4	Any required valuation reserve is charged to earnings when determined; and notes are charged off to the allowance as they are deemed uncollectible.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P77_S0	The asset underlying a direct financing lease contract is considered impaired if the estimated undiscounted future cash flows of the asset are less than its net book value.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P77_S1	The estimated undiscounted future cash flows are the sum of the estimated residual value of the asset at the end of the asset s expected holding period and estimates of undiscounted future rents.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P77_S2	The residual value assumes, among other things, that the asset is utilized normally in an open, unrestricted and stable market.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P77_S3	Short-term fluctuations in the market place are disregarded and it is assumed that there is no necessity either to dispose of a significant number of the assets, if held in quantity, simultaneously or to dispose of the asset quickly.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P78_S0	Impairment is measured as the difference between the fair value (as determined by a valuation method using discounted estimated future cash flows, third party appraisals or comparable sales of similar assets as applicable based on asset type) of the asset and its carrying value on the measurement date.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P79_S0	The Company s allowance for credit losses (related solely to financing receivables) and its recorded investment in financing receivables as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 were as follows (in thousands):
1394922_16_ITEM8_P80_S0	Includes $1 of unamortized initial direct costs.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P81_S0	Includes $4 of unamortized initial direct costs.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P82_S0	The Company evaluates the credit quality of its financing receivables on a scale equivalent to the following quality indicators related to corporate risk profiles:
1394922_16_ITEM8_P83_S0	Pass Any account whose lessee/debtor, co-lessee/debtor or any guarantor has a credit rating on publicly traded or privately placed debt issues as rated by Moody s or S P for either Senior Unsecured debt, Long Term Issuer rating or Issuer rating that are in the tiers of ratings generally recognized by the investment community as constituting an Investment Grade credit rating; or, has been determined by the Manager to be an Investment Grade Equivalent or High Quality Corporate Credit per its Credit Policy or has a Not Rated internal rating by the Manager and the account is not considered by the Chief Credit Officer of the manager to fall into one of the three risk profiles below.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P84_S0	Any traditional corporate type account with potential weaknesses (e.g. large net losses or major industry downturns) or, any growth capital account that has less than three months of cash as of the end of the calendar quarter to fund their continuing operations.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P84_S1	These accounts deserve management s close attention.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P84_S2	If left uncorrected, those potential weaknesses may result in deterioration of the Fund s receivable at some future date.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P85_S0	Substandard Any account that is inadequately protected by the current worth and paying capacity of the borrower or of the collateral pledged, if any.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P86_S0	Accounts that are so classified have a well-defined weakness or weaknesses that jeopardize the liquidation of the debt.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P86_S1	They are characterized by the distinct possibility that the Fund will sustain some loss as the likelihood of fully collecting all receivables may be questionable if the deficiencies are not corrected.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P86_S2	Such accounts are on the Manager s Credit Watch List.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P87_S0	Doubtful Any account where the weaknesses make collection or liquidation in full, on the basis of currently existing facts, conditions, and values, highly questionable and improbable.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P87_S1	Accordingly, an account that is so classified is on the Manager s Credit Watch List, and has been declared in default and the Manager has repossessed, or is attempting to repossess, the equipment it financed.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P88_S0	This category includes impaired notes and leases as applicable.

1394922_16_ITEM8_P90_S0	At December 31, 2015 and 2014, investment in financing receivables is aged as follows (in thousands):

1394922_16_ITEM8_P92_S0	Investments in equipment and leases, net:
1394922_16_ITEM8_P93_S0	The Company s investment in leases consists of the following (in thousands):
1394922_16_ITEM8_P94_S0	Recorded values of the Company s leased asset portfolio are reviewed each quarter to confirm the reasonableness of established residual values and to determine whether there is indication that an asset impairment might have taken place.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P94_S1	The Company uses a variety of sources and considers many factors in evaluating whether the respective book values of its assets are appropriate.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P94_S2	In addition, the company may direct a residual value review at any time if it becomes aware of issues regarding the ability of a lessee to continue to make payments on its lease contract.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P94_S3	An impairment loss is measured and recognized only if the estimated undiscounted future cash flows of the asset are less than their net book value.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P94_S4	The estimated undiscounted future cash flows are the sum of the residual value of the asset at the end of the asset s lease contract and undiscounted future rents from the existing lease contract.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P94_S5	The residual value assumes, among other things, that the asset is utilized normally in an open, unrestricted and stable market.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P94_S6	Short-term fluctuations in the marketplace are disregarded and it is assumed that there is no necessity either to dispose of a significant number of the assets, if held in quantity, simultaneously or to dispose of the asset quickly.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P95_S0	Impairment is measured as the difference between the fair value (as determined by a valuation method using discounted estimated future cash flows, third party appraisals or comparable sales of similar assets as applicable based on asset type) of the asset and its carrying value on the measurement date.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P95_S1	Upward adjustments for impairments recognized in prior periods are not made in any circumstances.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P96_S0	As a result of these reviews, management determined that no impairment losses existed during 2015.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P96_S1	By comparison, during 2014, the Company recorded fair value adjustments of $226 thousand to reduce the cost basis of certain impaired off-lease equipment.

1394922_16_ITEM8_P106_S0	The terms of the Operating Agreement provide that the Managing Member and/or affiliates are entitled to receive certain fees for equipment management and resale and for management of the Company.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P107_S0	The Operating Agreement allows for the reimbursement of costs incurred by Managing Member and/or affiliates for providing administrative services to the Company.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P107_S1	Administrative services provided include Company accounting, investor relations, legal counsel and lease and equipment documentation.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P107_S2	The Managing Member is not reimbursed for services whereby it is entitled to receive a separate fee as compensation for such services, such as management of investments.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P108_S0	The Company would be liable for certain future costs to be incurred by the Managing Member to manage the administrative services provided to the Company.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P109_S0	Each of AFS and ATEL Leasing Corporation ( ALC ) is a wholly-owned subsidiary of ATEL Capital Group and performs services for the Company on behalf of the Managing Member.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P109_S1	Acquisition services, equipment management, lease administration and asset disposition services are performed by ALC; investor relations, communications and general administrative services are performed by AFS.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P110_S0	Cost reimbursements to the Managing Member or its affiliates are based on its costs incurred in performing administrative services for the Company.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P110_S1	These costs are allocated to each managed entity based on certain criteria such as managed assets, number of investors or contributed capital based upon the type of cost incurred.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P110_S2	The Managing Member believes that the costs reimbursed are the lower of (i) actual costs incurred on behalf of the Company or (ii) the amount the Company would be required to pay independent parties for comparable administrative services in the same geographic location.

1394922_16_ITEM8_P112_S0	At December 31, 2015, non-recourse debt consists of notes payable to financial institutions.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P112_S1	The notes are due in monthly installments.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P112_S2	Interest on the notes is at fixed rates ranging from 1.97% to 2.39% per annum.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P112_S3	The notes are secured by assignments of lease payments and pledges of assets.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P112_S4	At December 31, 2015, gross lease rentals totaled approximately $1.1 million over the remaining lease terms; and the carrying value of the pledged assets is approximately $1.7 million.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P112_S5	The notes mature at various dates from 2017 through 2018.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P113_S0	The non-recourse debt does not contain any material financial covenants.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P113_S1	The debt is secured by liens granted by the Company to the non-recourse lenders on (and only on) the discounted lease transactions.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P113_S2	The lenders have recourse only to the following collateral: the specific leased equipment; the related lease chattel paper; the lease receivables; and proceeds of the foregoing items.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P113_S3	The non-recourse obligation is payable solely out of the respective specific security and the Company does not guarantee (nor is the Company otherwise contractually responsible for) the payment of the non-recourse debt as a general obligation or liability of the Company.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P113_S4	Although the Company does not have any direct or general liability in connection with the non-recourse debt apart from the security granted, the Company is directly and generally liable and responsible for certain representations, warranties, and covenants made to the lenders, such as warranties as to genuineness of the transaction parties signatures, as to the genuineness of the respective lease chattel paper or the transaction as a whole, or as to the Company s good title to or perfected interest in the secured collateral, as well as similar representations, warranties and covenants typically provided by non-recourse borrowers and customary in the equipment finance industry, and are viewed by such industry as being consistent with non-recourse discount financing obligations.
1394922_16_ITEM8_P113_S5	Accordingly, as there are no financial covenants or ratios imposed on the Company in connection with the non-recourse debt, the Company has determined that there are no material covenants with respect to the non-recourse debt that warrant footnote disclosure.
