1394922_17_ITEM8_P2_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1394922_17_ITEM8_P2_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P2_S2	The Company is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform, an audit of its internal control over financial reporting.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P2_S3	Our audits included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P2_S4	Accordingly, we express no such opinion.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P3_S0	An audit also includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P3_S1	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P4_S0	In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of ATEL 12, LLC as of December 31, 2016 and 2015, and the results of its operations and its cash flows for the years then ended, in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P5_S0	Organization and Limited Liability Company matters:
1394922_17_ITEM8_P6_S0	ATEL 12, LLC (the Company or the Fund ) was formed under the laws of the state of California on January 25, 2007 ( Date of Inception ) for the purpose of equipment financing and acquiring equipment to engage in equipment leasing and sales activities.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P6_S1	From its inception into the third quarter of 2013, the Managing Member was ATEL Associates 12, ( AA12 ), a Nevada limited liability company.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P6_S2	Effective September 30, 2013, AA12 was merged into ATEL Financial Services, LLC ( AFS or Managing Member or Manager ), a wholly-owned subsidiary of ATEL Capital Group.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P6_S3	The Fund may continue until December 31, 2030.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P7_S0	As a limited liability company, the liability of any individual member for the obligations of the Fund is limited to the extent of capital contributions to the Fund by the individual member.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P8_S0	The Company conducted a public offering of 20,000,000 Limited Liability Company Units ( Units ), at a price of $10 per Unit.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P8_S1	As of January 24, 2008, subscriptions for the minimum number of Units (120,000, representing $1.2 million), excluding subscriptions from Pennsylvania investors, had been received and the Fund requested subscription proceeds to be released from escrow.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P8_S2	On that date, the Company commenced initial operations and continued in its development stage activities until transitioning to an operating enterprise during the second quarter of 2008.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P9_S0	Pennsylvania subscriptions are subject to a separate escrow and are released to the Fund only when aggregate subscriptions for all investors equal to at least $7.5 million.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P9_S1	Total contributions to the Fund exceeded $7.5 million on July 15, 2008, at which time a request was processed to release the Pennsylvania escrowed amounts.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P9_S2	The offering was terminated on September 25, 2009.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P10_S0	As of December 31, 2016, cumulative gross contributions, less rescissions and repurchases (net of distributions paid and allocated syndication costs, as applicable), totaling $29.9 million (inclusive of the $500 initial Member s capital investment) have been received.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P10_S1	As of the same date, 2,992,482 Units were issued and outstanding.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P11_S0	The Company s principal objectives have been to invest in a diversified portfolio of investments that will (i) preserve, protect and return the Company s invested capital; (ii) generate regular cash distributions to Unitholders, with any balance remaining after required minimum distributions to be used to purchase additional investments during the Reinvestment Period (ending six calendar years after the completion of the Company s public offering of Units) and (iii) provide additional cash distributions following the Reinvestment Period and until all investment portfolio assets has been sold or otherwise disposed.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P12_S0	The Company is governed by the ATEL 12, LLC amended and restated Limited Liability Company Operating Agreement dated April 3, 2007 (the Operating Agreement ).
1394922_17_ITEM8_P13_S0	Pursuant to the terms of the Operating Agreement, the Managing Member and/or its affiliates receives compensation for services rendered and reimbursements for costs incurred on behalf of the Company (See Note 7, Related party transactions).
1394922_17_ITEM8_P14_S0	The Company is required to maintain reasonable cash reserves for working capital, the repurchase of Units and contingencies.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P14_S1	The repurchase of Units is solely at the discretion of the Managing Member.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P15_S0	The accompanying balance sheets as of December 31, 2016 and 2015, and the related statements of income, changes in members capital, and cash flows for the years then ended, have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( GAAP ) and the rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P15_S1	Certain prior year amounts may have been reclassified to conform to the current year presentation.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P15_S2	These reclassifications had no significant effect on the reported financial position or results from operations.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P16_S0	Footnote and tabular amounts are presented in thousands, except as to Units and per Unit data.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P17_S0	In preparing the accompanying financial statements, the Company has reviewed, as determined necessary by the Managing Member, events that have occurred after December 31, 2016, up until the issuance of the financial statements.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P17_S1	No events were noted which would require additional disclosure in the footnotes to the financial statements, and adjustments thereto.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P18_S0	Cash and cash equivalents include cash in banks and cash equivalent investments such as U.S. Treasury instruments with original and/or purchased maturities of ninety days or less.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P19_S0	The preparation of the financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P19_S1	Actual results could differ from the estimates.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P19_S2	Such estimates primarily relate to the determination of residual values at the end of the lease term and expected future cash flows used for impairment analysis purposes and for determination of the allowance for doubtful accounts and reserve for credit losses on notes receivable.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P20_S0	Accounts receivable represent the amounts billed under operating and direct financing lease contracts, and notes receivable which are currently due to the Company.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P20_S1	Allowances for doubtful accounts are typically established based on historical charge off and collection experience and the collectability of specifically identified lessees and borrowers, and invoiced amounts.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P20_S2	Accounts receivable deemed uncollectible are generally charged off against the allowance on a specific identification basis.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P21_S0	Recoveries of amounts that were previously written-off are recorded as other income in the period received.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P22_S0	Financial instruments that potentially subject the Company to concentrations of credit risk include cash and cash equivalents, operating and direct financing lease receivables, notes receivable and accounts receivable.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P22_S1	The Company places the majority of its cash deposits in noninterest-bearing accounts with financial institutions that have no less than $10 billion in assets.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P22_S2	Such deposits are insured up to $250 thousand.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P22_S3	The remainder of the Funds cash is temporarily invested in U.S. Treasury denominated instruments.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P22_S4	The concentration of such deposits and temporary cash investments is not deemed to create a significant risk to the Company.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P23_S0	Accounts and notes receivable represent amounts due from lessees or borrowers in various industries, related to equipment on operating and direct financing leases or notes receivable.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P24_S0	Equipment on operating leases and related revenue recognition:
1394922_17_ITEM8_P25_S0	Equipment subject to operating leases is stated at cost.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P25_S1	Depreciation is recognized on a straight-line method over the terms of the related leases to the equipment s estimated residual values.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P25_S2	Off-lease equipment is generally not subject to depreciation.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P25_S3	The Company depreciates all lease assets, in accordance with guidelines consistent with ASC 840-20-35-3, over the periods of the lease terms contained in each asset s respective lease contract to the estimated residual value at the end of the lease contract.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P25_S4	All lease assets were purchased only concurrent with the execution of a lease commitment by the lessee.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P25_S5	Thus, the original depreciation period corresponds with the term of the original lease.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P26_S0	Once the term of an original lease contract is completed, the subject property is typically sold to the existing user, re-leased to the existing user, or, when off-lease, is held for sale.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P26_S1	Assets which are re-leased continue to be depreciated using the terms of the new lease agreements and the estimated residual values at the end of the new lease terms, adjusted downward as necessary.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P27_S0	Assets classified as held-for-sale are carried at the lower of carrying amount, or the fair value less cost to sell (ASC 360-10-35-43).
1394922_17_ITEM8_P28_S0	The Company does not use the equipment held in its portfolio, but holds it solely for lease and ultimate sale.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P28_S1	In the course of marketing equipment that has come off-lease, management may determine at some point that re-leasing the assets may provide a superior return for investors and would then execute another lease.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P28_S2	Upon entering into a new lease contract, management will estimate the residual value once again and resume depreciation.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P29_S0	All lease assets, including off-lease assets, are subject to the Company s quarterly impairment analysis, as described below.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P29_S1	Maintenance costs associated with the Fund s portfolio of leased assets are expensed as incurred.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P29_S2	Major additions and betterments are capitalized.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P30_S0	Operating lease revenue is recognized on a straight-line basis over the term of the underlying leases.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P30_S1	The initial lease terms will vary as to the type of equipment subject to the leases, the needs of the lessees and the terms to be negotiated, but initial leases are generally on terms from 36 to 120 months.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P30_S2	The difference between rent received and rental revenue recognized is recorded as unearned operating lease income on the balance sheet.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P31_S0	Operating leases are generally placed in a non-accrual status (i.e., no revenue is recognized) when payments are more than 90 days past due.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P31_S1	Additionally, management considers the equipment underlying the lease contracts for impairment and periodically reviews the credit worthiness of all operating lessees with payments outstanding less than 90 days.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P31_S2	Based upon management s judgment, the related operating leases may be placed on non-accrual status.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P31_S3	Leases placed on non-accrual status are only returned to an accrual status when the account has been brought current and management believes recovery of the remaining unpaid lease payments is probable.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P31_S4	Until such time, revenues are recognized on a cash basis.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P32_S0	Direct financing leases and related revenue recognition:
1394922_17_ITEM8_P33_S0	Income from direct financing lease transactions is reported using the financing method of accounting, in which the Company s investment in the leased property is reported as a receivable from the lessee to be recovered through future rentals.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P33_S1	The interest income portion of each rental payment is calculated so as to generate a constant rate of return on the net receivable outstanding.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P34_S0	Allowances for losses on direct financing leases are typically established based on historical charge-off and collection experience and the collectability of specifically identified lessees and billed and unbilled receivables.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P34_S1	Direct financing leases are charged off to the allowance as they are deemed uncollectible.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P35_S0	Direct financing leases are generally placed in a non-accrual status (i.e., no revenue is recognized) and deemed impaired when payments are more than 90 days past due.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P35_S1	Additionally, management periodically reviews the creditworthiness of all direct finance lessees with payments outstanding less than 90 days.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P35_S2	Based upon management s judgment, the related direct financing leases may be placed on non-accrual status.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P35_S3	Leases placed on non-accrual status are only returned to an accrual status when the account has been brought current and management believes recovery of the remaining unpaid lease payments is probable.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P35_S4	Until such time, all payments received are applied only against outstanding principal balances.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P36_S0	Notes receivable, unearned interest income and related revenue recognition:
1394922_17_ITEM8_P37_S0	The Company records all future payments of principal and interest on notes as notes receivable, which are then offset by the amount of any related unearned interest income.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P37_S1	For financial statement purposes, the Company reports only the net amount of principal due on the balance sheet.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P37_S2	The unearned interest is recognized over the term of the note and the income portion of each note payment is calculated so as to generate a constant rate of return on the net balance outstanding.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P37_S3	Any fees or costs related to notes receivable are recorded as part of the net investment in notes receivable and amortized over the term of the loan.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P38_S0	Allowances for losses on notes receivable are typically established based on historical charge off and collection experience and the collectability of specifically identified borrowers and billed and unbilled receivables.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P38_S1	Notes are considered impaired when, based on current information and events, it is probable that the Company will be unable to collect the scheduled payments of principal and/or interest when due according to the contractual terms of the note agreement.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P38_S2	Factors considered by management in determining impairment include payment status, collateral value, and the probability of collecting scheduled principal and interest payments when due.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P38_S3	If it is determined that a loan is impaired with regard to scheduled payments, the Company will perform an analysis of the note to determine if an impairment valuation reserve is necessary.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P38_S4	This analysis considers the estimated cash flows from the note, or the collateral value of the property underlying the note when note repayment is collateral dependent.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P38_S5	Any required valuation reserve is charged to earnings when determined; and notes are charged off to the allowance as they are deemed uncollectible.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P39_S0	Notes receivable are generally placed in a non-accrual status (i.e., no revenue is recognized) when payments are more than 90 days past due.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P39_S1	Additionally, management periodically reviews the creditworthiness of companies with note payments outstanding less than 90 days.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P39_S2	Based upon management s judgment, the related notes may be placed on non-accrual status.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P39_S3	Notes placed on non-accrual status are only returned to an accrual status when the account has been brought current and management believes recovery of the remaining unpaid receivable is probable.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P39_S4	Until such time, all payments received are applied only against outstanding principal balances.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P40_S0	The Company capitalizes initial direct costs ( IDC ) associated with the origination and funding of lease assets and investments in notes receivable.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P40_S1	IDC includes both internal costs (e.g., the costs of employees activities in connection with successful lease and loan originations) and external broker fees incurred with such originations.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P40_S2	The costs are amortized on a lease by lease (or note by note) basis based on actual lease term using a straight-line method for operating leases and the effective interest rate method for direct financing leases and notes receivable.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P40_S3	Upon disposal of the underlying lease assets and notes receivable, both the initial direct costs and the associated accumulated amortization are relieved.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P40_S4	Costs related to leases or notes receivable that are not consummated are not eligible for capitalization as initial direct costs and are expensed as acquisition expense.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P41_S0	Acquisition expense represents costs which include, but are not limited to, legal fees and expenses, travel and communication expenses, cost of appraisals, accounting fees and expenses and miscellaneous expenses related to the selection and acquisition of equipment which are reimbursable to the Managing Member under the terms of the Operating Agreement.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P41_S1	As the costs are not eligible for capitalization as initial direct costs, such amounts are expensed as incurred.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P42_S0	Recorded values of the Company s leased asset portfolio are reviewed each quarter to confirm the reasonableness of established residual values and to determine whether there is indication that an asset impairment might have taken place.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P42_S1	The Company uses a variety of sources and considers many factors in evaluating whether the respective book values of its assets are appropriate.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P42_S2	In addition, the company may direct a residual value review at any time if it becomes aware of issues regarding the ability of a lessee to continue to make payments on its lease contract.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P42_S3	An impairment loss is measured and recognized only if the estimated undiscounted future cash flows of the asset are less than their net book value.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P42_S4	The estimated undiscounted future cash flows are the sum of the residual value of the asset at the end of the asset s lease contract and undiscounted future rents from the existing lease contract.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P42_S5	The residual value assumes, among other things, that the asset is utilized normally in an open, unrestricted and stable market.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P42_S6	Short-term fluctuations in the marketplace are disregarded and it is assumed that there is no necessity either to dispose of a significant number of the assets, if held in quantity, simultaneously or to dispose of the asset quickly.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P43_S0	Impairment is measured as the difference between the fair value (as determined by a valuation method using discounted estimated future cash flows, third party appraisals or comparable sales of similar assets as applicable based on asset type) of the asset and its carrying value on the measurement date.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P43_S1	Upward adjustments for impairments recognized in prior periods are not made in any circumstances.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P44_S0	The Company is organized into one operating segment for the purpose of making operating decisions or assessing performance.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P44_S1	Accordingly, the Company operates in one reportable operating segment in the United States.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P45_S0	The Company s principal decision makers are the Managing Member s Chief Executive Officer and its Chief Financial Officer and Chief Operating Officer.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P46_S0	leasing transaction portfolio; c) the Company does not maintain discrete financial information on any specific segment other than its equipment financing operations; d) the Company has not chosen to organize its business around different products and services other than equipment lease financing; and e) the Company has not chosen to organize its business around geographic areas.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P47_S0	The primary geographic region in which the Company seeks leasing opportunities is North America.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P47_S1	As of and for the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015, all of the Company s current operating revenues and long-lived assets relate to customers domiciled in the United States.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P48_S0	From time to time, the Company may purchase securities of its borrowers or receive warrants to purchase securities in connection with its lending arrangements.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P49_S0	Purchased securities are generally not registered for public sale and are carried at cost.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P49_S1	Such securities are adjusted to fair value if the fair value is less than the carrying value and such impairment is deemed by the Managing Member to be other than temporary.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P50_S0	Factors considered by the Managing Member in determining fair value include, but are not limited to, available financial information, the issuer s ability to meet its current obligations and indications of the issuer s subsequent ability to raise capital.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P51_S0	The Company had $272 thousand and $300 thousand of purchased securities at December 31, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P51_S1	Based upon the Company s review of its portfolio, no fair value adjustment was deemed necessary for 2016 and 2015.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P52_S0	Warrants owned by the Company are not registered for public sale, but are considered derivatives and are reflected at an estimated fair value on the balance sheet as determined by the Managing Member.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P52_S1	The Company recorded unrealized losses of $168 thousand and $66 thousand on fair value adjustment of its warrants during 2016 and 2015, respectively.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P52_S2	The unrealized losses recorded during 2016 reduced the estimated fair value of the Company s portfolio of warrants to $159 thousand at December 31, 2016 from $327 thousand at December 31, 2015.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P52_S3	The Company realized no gains or losses from the net exercise of warrants during 2016.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P52_S4	The Company realized gains of $147 thousand on the net exercise of certain warrants in 2015.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P53_S0	The Company records prepayments on operating leases as a liability under the caption of unearned operating lease income.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P53_S1	The liability is recorded when prepayments are received and recognized as operating lease revenue over the period to which the prepayments relate using a straight-line method.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P54_S0	The Company is treated as a partnership for federal income tax purposes.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P54_S1	Pursuant to the provisions of Section 701 of the Internal Revenue Code, a partnership is not subject to federal income taxes.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P54_S2	Accordingly, the Company has provided current franchise income taxes for only those states which levy income taxes on partnerships.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P54_S3	For the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015, the related provision for state income taxes was approximately $27 thousand and $64 thousand, respectively.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P54_S4	The Company does not have any entity level uncertain tax positions.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P55_S0	The Company files income tax returns in the U.S. federal jurisdiction and various state jurisdictions and is generally subject to examination by U.S. federal (or state and local) income tax authorities for three years from the filing of a tax return.

1394922_17_ITEM8_P60_S0	In August 2016, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued Accounting Standards Update 2016-15 Statement of Cash Flows (Topic 230): Classification of Certain Cash Receipts and Cash Payments ( ASU 2016-15 ).
1394922_17_ITEM8_P60_S1	ASU 2016-15 addresses specific cash flow issues with the objective of reducing the existing diversity in practice.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P60_S2	The amendments in this Update are effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2017, and interim periods within those fiscal years.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P60_S3	Management is currently evaluating the standard and its impact on operations and financial reporting.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P61_S0	In June 2016, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update 2016-13, Financial Instruments Credit Losses (Topic 326) ( ASU 2016-13 ).
1394922_17_ITEM8_P61_S1	The main objective of this Update is to provide financial statement users with more decision-useful information about the expected credit losses on financial instruments and other commitments to extend credit held by a reporting entity at each reporting date.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P61_S2	To achieve this objective, the amendments in this Update replace the incurred loss impairment methodology in current GAAP with a methodology that reflects expected credit losses and requires consideration of a broader range of reasonable and supportable information to inform credit loss estimates.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P62_S0	The amendments affect entities holding financial assets and net investment in leases that are not accounted for at fair value through net income.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P62_S1	The amendments affect loans, debt securities, trade receivables, net investments in leases, off-balance-sheet credit exposures, reinsurance receivables, and any other financial assets not excluded from the scope that have the contractual right to receive cash.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P62_S2	ASU 2016-13 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2019, including interim periods within those fiscal years.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P62_S3	Early adoption is permitted for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P63_S0	Management is currently evaluating the standard and its operational and related disclosure requirements.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P64_S0	In February 2016, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update 2016-02, Leases (Topic 842) ( ASU 2016-02 ).
1394922_17_ITEM8_P64_S1	The new standard will require lessees to recognize lease assets and lease liabilities arising from operating leases with lease terms greater than 12 months in the statement of financial position.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P65_S0	unchanged from the previous lease accounting GAAP.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P66_S0	Certain changes were made to the lessor accounting guidance in order to align the lessor accounting with the lessee accounting model and Topic 606, Revenue from Contracts with Customers.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P66_S1	Similar to the previous guidance, lessors will classify leases as operating, direct financing, or sales-type.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P66_S2	Lessors in operating leases will continue to recognize the underlying asset and recognize income on a straight-line basis.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P67_S0	Lessors determine whether a lease is a sale of the underlying asset based on whether the lessee effectively obtains control of the underlying assets.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P68_S0	ASU-2016-02 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018, including interim periods within those fiscal years.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P68_S1	Management will adopt the standard and is currently evaluating the standard and its operational and related disclosure requirements.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P69_S0	(Subtopic 825-10): Recognition and Measurement of Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities ( ASU 2016-01 ).
1394922_17_ITEM8_P69_S1	The new standard provides guidance related to accounting for equity investments and financial liabilities under the fair value option, and the presentation and disclosure requirements for financial instruments.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P69_S2	In addition, the FASB clarified guidance related to the valuation allowance assessment when recognizing deferred tax assets resulting from unrealized losses on available-for-sale debt securities.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P70_S0	ASU 2016-01 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2017, including interim periods within those fiscal years.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P70_S1	Management will adopt the standard and is currently evaluating the standard and its operational and related disclosure requirements.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P71_S0	In August 2014, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update 2014-15, Presentation of Financial Statements Going Concern (Subtopic 205-40): Disclosure of Uncertainties about an Entity s Ability to Continue as a Going Concern ( ASU-2014-15 ).
1394922_17_ITEM8_P71_S1	The new standard provides guidance relative to management s responsibility to evaluate whether there is substantial doubt about an entity s ability to continue as a going concern and to provide related footnote disclosures.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P71_S2	The new standard is effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those fiscal years, beginning after December 15, 2016.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P71_S3	Management does not expect the adoption of ASU 2014-15 to have a material impact on the Company s financial statements or related disclosures.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P72_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers ( ASU 2014-09 ), which amends the existing accounting standards for revenue recognition.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P72_S1	ASU 2014-09 is based on principles that govern the recognition of revenue at an amount an entity expects to be entitled when products are transferred to customers.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P72_S2	On July 9, 2015, the FASB approved the deferral of the effective date of ASU 2014-09 by one year and in August 2015, issued Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606): Deferral of the Effective Date ( ASU 2015-14 ).
1394922_17_ITEM8_P72_S3	ASU 2015-14 is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2017, including interim periods within that reporting period.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P72_S4	Earlier application is permitted only as of annual reporting periods beginning after December 31, 2016, including interim reporting periods within that reporting period.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P72_S5	The new revenue standard may be applied retrospectively to each prior period presented or retrospectively with the cumulative effect recognized as of the date of adoption.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P72_S6	The Company evaluated the impact of the new standard on its financial statements and has determined that such impact is virtually non-existent as the new revenue guideline does not affect revenues from leases and loans, which comprise the majority of the Company s revenues.

1394922_17_ITEM8_P96_S0	The Company evaluates the credit quality of its financing receivables on a scale equivalent to the following quality indicators related to corporate risk profiles:
1394922_17_ITEM8_P97_S0	Pass Any account whose lessee/debtor, co-lessee/debtor or any guarantor has a credit rating on publicly traded or privately placed debt issues as rated by Moody s or S P for either Senior Unsecured debt, Long Term Issuer rating or Issuer rating that are in the tiers of ratings generally recognized by the investment community as constituting an Investment Grade credit rating; or, has been determined by the Manager to be an Investment Grade Equivalent or High Quality Corporate Credit per its Credit Policy or has a Not Rated internal rating by the Manager and the account is not considered by the Chief Credit Officer of the manager to fall into one of the three risk profiles below.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P98_S0	Any traditional corporate type account with potential weaknesses (e.g. large net losses or major industry downturns) or, any growth capital account that has less than three months of cash as of the end of the calendar quarter to fund their continuing operations.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P98_S1	These accounts deserve management s close attention.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P98_S2	If left uncorrected, those potential weaknesses may result in deterioration of the Fund s receivable at some future date.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P99_S0	Substandard Any account that is inadequately protected by the current worth and paying capacity of the borrower or of the collateral pledged, if any.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P100_S0	Accounts that are so classified have a well-defined weakness or weaknesses that jeopardize the liquidation of the debt.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P100_S1	They are characterized by the distinct possibility that the Fund will sustain some loss as the likelihood of fully collecting all receivables may be questionable if the deficiencies are not corrected.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P100_S2	Such accounts are on the Manager s Credit Watch List.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P101_S0	Doubtful Any account where the weaknesses make collection or liquidation in full, on the basis of currently existing facts, conditions, and values, highly questionable and improbable.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P101_S1	Accordingly, an account that is so classified is on the Manager s Credit Watch List, and has been declared in default and the Manager has repossessed, or is attempting to repossess, the equipment it financed.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P102_S0	This category includes impaired notes and leases as applicable.

1394922_17_ITEM8_P106_S0	The terms of the Operating Agreement provide that the Managing Member and/or affiliates are entitled to receive certain fees for equipment management and resale and for management of the Company.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P107_S0	The Operating Agreement allows for the reimbursement of costs incurred by the Managing Member and/or affiliates for providing administrative services to the Company.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P107_S1	Administrative services provided include Company accounting, investor relations, legal counsel and lease and equipment documentation.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P107_S2	The Managing Member is not reimbursed for services whereby it is entitled to receive a separate fee as compensation for such services, such as management of investments.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P108_S0	Each of AFS and ATEL Leasing Corporation ( ALC ) is a wholly-owned subsidiary of ATEL Capital Group, Inc. and performs services for the Company on behalf of the Managing Member.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P108_S1	Acquisition services, equipment management, lease administration and asset disposition services are performed by ALC; investor relations, communications and general administrative services are performed by AFS.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P109_S0	Cost reimbursements to the Managing Member or its affiliates are based on its costs incurred in performing administrative services for the Company.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P109_S1	These costs are allocated to each managed entity based on certain criteria such as total assets, number of investors or contributed capital based upon the type of cost incurred.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P109_S2	The Managing Member believes that the costs reimbursed are the lower of (i) actual costs incurred on behalf of the Company or (ii) the amount the Company would be required to pay independent parties for comparable administrative services in the same geographic location.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P110_S0	The Managing Member and/or affiliates earned fees and billed for reimbursements, pursuant to the Operating Agreement, during the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 as follows (in thousands):
1394922_17_ITEM8_P111_S0	At December 31, 2016, non-recourse debt consists of notes payable to financial institutions.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P111_S1	The notes are due in monthly installments.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P111_S2	Interest on the notes is at fixed rates ranging from 1.97% to 2.39% per annum.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P111_S3	The notes are secured by assignments of lease payments and pledges of assets.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P111_S4	At December 31, 2016, gross operating lease rentals totaled approximately $581 thousand over the remaining lease terms; and the carrying value of the pledged assets is $1.4 million.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P111_S5	The notes mature at various dates from 2017 through 2018.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P112_S0	The non-recourse debt does not contain any material financial covenants.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P112_S1	The debt is secured by a specific lien granted by the Company to the non-recourse lender on (and only on) the discounted lease transactions.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P112_S2	The lender has recourse only to the following collateral: the leased equipment; the related lease chattel paper; the lease receivables; and proceeds of the foregoing items.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P112_S3	The non-recourse obligation is payable solely out of the respective specific security and the Company does not guarantee (nor is the Company otherwise contractually responsible for) the payment of the non-recourse debt as a general obligation or liability of the Company.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P112_S4	Although the Company does not have any direct or general liability in connection with the non-recourse debt apart from the security granted, the Company is directly and generally liable and responsible for certain representations, warranties, and covenants made to the lender, such as warranties as to genuineness of the transaction parties signatures, as to the genuineness of the respective lease chattel paper or the transaction as a whole, or as to the Company s good title to or perfected interest in the secured collateral, as well as similar representations, warranties and covenants typically provided by non-recourse borrowers and customary in the equipment finance industry, and are viewed by such industry as being consistent with non-recourse discount financing obligations.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P112_S5	Accordingly, as there are no financial covenants or ratios imposed on the Company in connection with the non-recourse debt, the Company has determined that there are no material covenants with respect to the non-recourse debt that warrant footnote disclosure.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P113_S0	Future minimum payments of non-recourse debt are as follows (in thousands):
1394922_17_ITEM8_P114_S0	At December 31, 2016, there were no commitments to purchase lease assets and fund investments in notes receivable.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P115_S0	The Company enters into contracts that contain a variety of indemnifications.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P115_S1	The Company s maximum exposure under these arrangements is unknown.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P115_S2	However, the Company has not had prior claims or losses pursuant to these contracts and expects the risk of loss to be remote.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P116_S0	The Managing Member knows of no facts or circumstances that would make the Company s contractual commitments outside standard mutual covenants applicable to commercial transactions between businesses.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P116_S1	Accordingly, the Company believes that these indemnification obligations are made in the ordinary course of business as part of standard commercial and industry practice, and that any potential liability under the Company s similar commitments is remote.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P116_S2	Should any such indemnification obligation become payable, the Company would separately record and/or disclose such liability in accordance with GAAP.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P117_S0	A total of 2,992,482 Units were issued and outstanding at December 31, 2016 and 2015, including the 50 Units issued to the initial Member (Managing Member).
1394922_17_ITEM8_P117_S1	The Fund was authorized to issue up to 20,000,000 Units in addition to the Units issued to the initial Member.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P118_S0	The Company has the right, exercisable at the Managing Member s discretion, but not the obligation, to repurchase Units of a Unitholder who ceases to be a U.S. Citizen, for a price equal to 100% of the holder s capital account.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P118_S1	The Company is otherwise permitted, but not required, to repurchase Units upon a holder s request.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P118_S2	The repurchase of Fund units is made in accordance with Section 13 of the Amended and Restated Limited Liability Company Operating Agreement.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P118_S3	The repurchase would be at the discretion of the Managing Member on terms it determines to be appropriate under given circumstances, in the event that the Managing Member deems such repurchase to be in the best interest of the Company; provided, the Company is never required to repurchase any Units.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P118_S4	Upon the repurchase of any Units by the Fund, the tendered Units are cancelled.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P119_S0	All Units repurchased during a quarter are deemed to be repurchased effective the last day of the preceding quarter, and are not deemed to be outstanding during, or entitled to allocations of net income, net loss or distributions for the quarter in which such repurchase occurs.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P119_S1	No units were repurchased during 2016 or 2015.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P120_S0	The Fund s net income or net losses are to be allocated 100% to the Members.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P120_S1	From the commencement of the Fund until the initial closing date, net income and net loss were allocated 99% to the Managing Member and 1% to the initial members.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P120_S2	Commencing with the initial closing date, net income and net loss are to be allocated 92.5% to the Other Members and 7.5% to the Managing Member.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P121_S0	Fund distributions are to be allocated 7.5% to the Managing Member and 92.5% to the Other Members.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P121_S1	The Company commenced periodic distributions in December 2008.

1394922_17_ITEM8_P123_S0	Fair value measurements and disclosures are based on a fair value hierarchy as determined by significant inputs used to measure fair value.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P123_S1	The three levels of inputs within the fair value hierarchy are defined as follows:
1394922_17_ITEM8_P124_S0	Level 1 Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P125_S0	An active market for the asset or liability is a market in which transactions for the asset or liability occur with sufficient frequency and volume to provide pricing information on an ongoing basis, generally on a national exchange.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P126_S0	Level 2 Quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active, and model-based valuations in which all significant inputs are observable in the market.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P127_S0	Level 3 Valuation is modeled using significant inputs that are unobservable in the market.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P127_S1	These unobservable inputs reflect the Company s own estimates of assumptions that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P128_S0	At December 31, 2016 and 2015, only the Company s warrants were measured on a recurring basis.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P128_S1	During 2016, the Company had no non-recurring adjustments to reduce the cost basis of certain assets deemed impaired.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P128_S2	During 2015, the Company recorded non-recurring adjustments to reduce the cost basis of certain investment in securities deemed impaired in 2015.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P129_S0	The Company s valuation policy is determined by members of the Asset Management, Credit and Accounting departments.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P129_S1	Whenever possible, the policy is to obtain quoted market prices in active markets to estimate fair values for recognition and disclosure purposes.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P129_S2	Where quoted market prices in active markets are not available, fair values are estimated using discounted cash flow analyses, broker quotes, information from third party remarketing agents, third party appraisals of collateral and/or other valuation techniques.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P129_S3	These techniques are significantly affected by certain of the Company s assumptions, including discount rates and estimates of future cash flows.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P129_S4	Potential taxes and other transaction costs are not considered in estimating fair values.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P130_S0	As the Company is responsible for determining fair value, an analysis is performed on prices obtained from third parties.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P130_S1	Such analysis is performed by asset management and credit department personnel who are familiar with the Company s investments in equipment, notes receivable and equity securities of venture companies.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P130_S2	The analysis may include a periodic review of price fluctuations and validation of numbers obtained from a specific third party by reference to multiple representative sources.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P131_S0	Such fair value adjustments utilized the following methodology:
1394922_17_ITEM8_P132_S0	Warrants owned by the Company are not registered for public sale, but are considered derivatives and are carried on the balance sheet at an estimated fair value at the end of the period.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P132_S1	The valuation of the warrants was determined using a Black-Scholes formulation of value based upon the stock price(s), the exercise price(s), the volatility of comparable venture companies, and a risk free interest rate for the term(s) of the warrant exercise(s).
1394922_17_ITEM8_P132_S2	As of December 31, 2016 and 2015, the calculated fair value of the Fund s warrant portfolio approximated $159 thousand and $327 thousand, respectively.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P133_S0	Such valuations are classified within Level 3 of the valuation hierarchy.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P134_S0	The following table reconciles the beginning and ending balances of the Company s Level 3 recurring assets (in thousands):
1394922_17_ITEM8_P135_S0	As of December 31, 2016, the Company had no notes receivable.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P135_S1	As of December 31, 2015, the Company had $309 thousand in notes receivable and no impairment adjustment was recorded.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P136_S0	The Company s investment securities are not registered for public sale and are carried at cost.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P136_S1	The investment securities are adjusted for impairment, if any, based upon factors which include, but are not limited to, available financial information, the issuer s ability to meet its current obligations and indications of the issuer s subsequent ability to raise capital.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P137_S0	During 2016 and 2015, the Company recorded no fair value adjustments to reduce the cost basis of investment securities.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P137_S1	A majority of the reduction in value was based on a market approach technique and uses inputs that reflect qualitative and quantitative information provided by the management of the investee, which indicated reduced growth opportunity and eventual reduction in cash flows and revenues.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P138_S0	Under the Fair Value Measurements Topic of the FASB Accounting Standards Codification, the fair value of impaired assets is classified within Level 3 of the valuation hierarchy.
1394922_17_ITEM8_P139_S0	The following table presents the fair value measurements of impaired investment securities measured at fair value on a non-recurring basis during and the level within the hierarchy in which the fair value measurements fall at December 31, 2015 (in thousands):
